Revision 1.20 2004/10/18 18:17:47 packel added div0s; changed orth ʼa)da/mas,ʼ to a)da/mas
Revision 1.19 2004/10/07 14:18:11 packel removed *s in entry keys
Revision 1.18 2004/10/05 21:34:13 packel Aligned dictionary entries with the LSJ.
Revision 1.17 2004/09/08 15:49:42 packel Changed doctype to TEI P4
Revision 1.16 2004/09/01 15:44:25 packel Fixed thirty-odd words that had multiple entries but no number afterward to differentiate the entries (e.g., si=gma, si=gma is now si=gma1, si=gma2).
Revision 1.15 2004/06/15 19:31:34 lcerrato changed nothwithstanding to notwithstanding
Revision 1.14 2003/02/04 21:21:51 lcerrato fixed typo kuma entry swoln to swollen

Revision 1.12 2001/04/20 21:58:57 dasmith Added funder.

Revision 1.7 1998/08/24 19:15:31 jrydberg finished trans tags and added new prep. defs.

Revision 1.4 1998/08/19 18:23:58 jrydberg Corrected trans tagging for short defs. through a)mfote/rwqen.

Revision 1.1 1998/08/14 15:38:33 textgod Added to repository.

div1.head: δαγύς
div1.sense: a wax doll, puppet, Theocr.

div1.head: δᾳδίον
div1.sense: used of firewood, Ar.

div1.head: δᾳδίς
div1.sense: a torch-feast, Luc.

div1.head: δᾳδουχέω
div1.sense: to hold the office of δαιδοῦχος, to carry a torch, esp. in pageants, Eur.

div1.head: δᾳδοῦχος
div1.sense: a torch-bearer, an officer at the mysteries of Eleusinian Demeter, Arist.

div1.head: δᾳδοφορέω
div1.sense: to carry torches, Luc.

div1.head: δαήμων
div1.sense: knowing, experienced in a thing, ἔν τινι Il.; c. gen., Od.:— δαημονέστατος Xen.

div1.head: δαήρ
div1.sense: a husbandʼs brother, brother, in-law, Lat. levir, answering to the fem. γάλως, Il.

div1.head: δαιδάλεος
div1.sense: cunningly or curiously wrought, of work in metal or wood, Hom.; of embroidery, Hes., Eur.
cunning, of the artificerʼs skill, Anth.

div1.head: δαιδάλλω
div1.sense: to work cunningly, deck or inlay with curious arts, to embellish, Hom.:—Pass., perf. part. δεδαιδαλμένος, Pind.

div1.head: δαίδαλμα
div1.sense: a work of art, Theocr.

div1.head: δαίδαλος
div1.sense: cunningly or curiously wrought, Aesch.: in Hom. only in neut. as Subst., δαίδαλα πάντα all cunning works, Il.; so in sg., Od.
as prop. n., Δαίδαλος, ὁ, Daedalus, i. e. the cunning worker, the artist, from Cnosus in Crete, contemporary with Minos, mentioned in Il. as maker of a χορός for Ariadne.

div1.head: δαιδαλόχειρ
div1.sense: cunning of hand, Anth.

div1.head: δαΐζω
div1.sense: to cleave asunder, cleave, Hom., Aesch.
to slay, smite, Il., Aesch.
to rend, tear, χερσὶ κόμην ἤισχυνε δαΐζων Il.:—Pass., χαλκῷ δεδαϊγμένος Il.; δεδαϊγμένος ἦτορ through the heart, Il.; δεδαϊγμένον ἦτορ a heart torn by misery, Od.; δαϊχθείς Pind., Eur.
simply, to divide, ἐδαΐζετο θυμὸς ἐνὶ στήθεσσιν his soul was divided within him, i. e. was in doubt, Il.; δαϊζόμενος κατὰ θυμὸν διχθάδια divided or doubting between two opinions, Il.

div1.head: δαϊκτήρ
div1.sense: a slayer:— as adj. heart-rending, Aesch.

div1.head: δαιμονάω
div1.sense: to be under the power of a δαίμων, to suffer by a divine visitation, δαιμονᾶν κακοῖς to be plunged in heaven-sent woes, Aesch.; so, δ. ἐν ἄται Aesch.:— absol. to be possessed, to be mad, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: δαιμονίζομαι
div1.sense: Mid. to be possessed by a demon or evil spirit, NTest.

div1.head: δαιμόνιον
div1.sense: the Deity, Lat. numen, or divine operation, Hdt., Eur., etc.: a fatality, Dem.
an inferior divine being, a demon, Xen., Plat.
a demon, evil spirit, NTest.

div1.head: δαιμόνιος
div1.sense: of or belonging to a δαίμων:

voc. δαιμόνιε, δαιμονίη, mostly in the way of reproach, thou luckless wight! thou wretch! sirrah! madam! Il.;—more rarely by way of admiration, noble sir! excellent man! Il., Hes.; also by way of pity, poor wretch! so in Hdt., δαιμόνιε ἀνδρῶν; also in an iron. sense, my good fellow! good sir! ὦ δαιμόνιʼ ἀνδρῶν, ὦ δαιμόνιʼ, ὦ δαιμόνιʼ ἀνθρώπων Ar., Plat.
anything proceeding from the Deity, heaven-sent, divine, miraculous, Hdt., Attic; εἰ μή τι δαιμόνιον εἴη were it not a divine intervention, Xen.; τὰ δαιμόνια visitations of Heaven, Thuc.
of persons, divine, excellent, Plat.
adv. -ως, by Divine power, marvellously, Ar.:—so neut. pl. δαιμόνια Ar., Xen.; δαιμονιώτατα most clearly by the hand of the gods, Xen.

div1.head: δαιμονιώδης
div1.sense: demoniacal, devilish, NTest.

div1.head: δαίμων
div1.etym: Perh. from δαίω B, to divide or distribute destinies.
div1.sense: a god, goddess, like θεός, θεά, Hom., Trag., etc.:—in Hom. also deity or divine power (θεός denotes a god in person), Lat. numen; πρὸς δαίμονα against the divine power; σὺν δαίμονι with it, by its favour, Il.:—so, κατὰ δαίμονα, nearly = τύχηι, by chance, Hdt.; ἐν τῶι δ. θεῶν ἐν γούνασι, Soph.
oneʼs daemon or genius, oneʼs lot or fortune, στυγερὸς δαίμων Od.; δαίμονος αἶσα κακή Od.: absol. good or ill fortune, Trag.; esp. of the evil genius of a family, Aesch.
δαίμονες, in Hes., are the souls of men of the golden age, forming the link between gods and men:—later, of any departed souls, Lat. manes, lemures, Luc.
in NTest. an evil spirit, a demon, devil.

div1.head: δαίνυμι
div1.sense: to divide :—to give a banquet or feast, δαίνυ δαῖτα γέρουσι Il.; δ. γάμον to give a marriage-feast, Hom.; δ. τάφον to give a funeral feast, Hom.
c. acc. pers. to feast one, Hdt.; ζῶν μὲ δαίσεις thou shalt be my living feast, Aesch.
Mid. to have a feast given one, to feast, Hom., Hdt.
c. acc. to feast on, consume, eat, Hdt.; μίαν δ. τράπεζαν to eat at a common table, Theocr.:— also of poison, to consume, Soph.

div1.head: δάϊος
div1.etym: In signf. II from *δάω, δαῆναι: in signf. I perh. from δαΐς battle.
div1.sense: hostile, destructive, dreadful, epith. of πῦρ, burning, consuming, Il., Trag.:— δάϊοι, δᾶιοι enemies, Aesch., Soph.; in sg. an enemy, Ar.; hence as adj. hostile, Ar.
unhappy, wretched, Trag.
knowing, cunning, Anth.

div1.head: δαϊόφρων
div1.sense: unhappy in mind, miserable, Aesch.

div1.head: δαί
div1.sense: colloquial form of δή used after interrogatives, τί δαὶ λέγεις σύ; Ar.; τί δαί; what? how? Ar., Plat.

div1.head: δαΐς
div1.sense: a fire-brand, pine-torch, Lat. taeda, Hom.
as collective noun, pine-wood, such as torches were made of, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: δάϊς
div1.sense: war, battle, Hom., Aesch.

div1.head: δαίς
div1.etym: δαίω, to divide a meal, feast, banquet
div1.sense: often in Hom., who calls the usual meal δαὶς ἐΐση, equally divided; Θυέστου δαῖτα παιδείων κρεῶν the feast of Thyestes on the flesh of his children, Aesch.; in pl., Od.
of the meat or food itself, Eur.

div1.head: δαιταλεύς
div1.sense: a banqueter, feaster, Aesch., Ar.

div1.head: δαίτηθεν
div1.sense: from a feast, Od., Theocr.

div1.head: δαίτη
div1.sense: poet. for δαίς, a feast, banquet, Il.

div1.head: δαιτρεύω
div1.sense: to cut up meat, cut into joints or to carve, Od.: to cut up for distribution among the people, Il.

div1.head: δαιτρόν
div1.sense: oneʼs portion, δαιτρὸν πίνειν Il.

div1.head: δαιτρός
div1.sense: one that carves meat, a carver, Od.

div1.head: δαιτροσύνη
div1.sense: the art of carving meat, a helping at table, Od.

div1.head: δαιτυμών
div1.sense: one that is entertained, an invited guest, in pl., Hom., Hdt.:—in sg., Plat.; ὁ ξένων δαιτυμών who makes his meal on strangers, Eur.

div1.head: δαιτύς
div1.sense: a meal, Il.

div1.head: δαΐφρων
div1.sense: in Il., mostly, of warriors; in Od., of Ulysses. In the first case (from δάϊς battle, φρήν) of warlike mind, warlike;— in the second (from *δάω, φρήν) wise of mind, prudent. Others take *δάω as the Root in all cases, and translate skilful, proved.

div1.head: δαίω
div1.etym: The Root is !δαϝ, which appears in the perf. pass. part. δεδαυμένος, Semon.
the perfect and pluperfect forms are commonly used with the present and imperfect meanings.
div1.sense: to light up, make to burn, kindle, Lat. accendo, Il., Aesch.:—Pass. to blaze, burn fiercely, Il.; πυρὶ ὄσσε δεδήει blazed with fire, Od.; metaph., πόλεμος, μάχη δέδηε war blazes forth, Il.; ὄσσα δεδήει the report spread like wild-fire, Lat. flagrat rumor, Il.
to burn, burn up, Lat. uro:— Pass., δαισθείς Eur.

div1.head: δαίω
div1.sense: to divide; for the Act., δαΐζω is used:— Pass., δαίεται ἦτορ Od.; Epic 3rd pl. perf., διχθὰ δεδαίαται are divided in two, Od.:—Mid. to distribute, κρέα Od.—The aor1 ἔδαισα, ἐδαισάμην belong to δαίνυμι; fut. δάσομαι, aor1 ἐδασάμην to δατέομαι.

div1.head: δακέθυμος
div1.sense: heart-eating, heart-vexing, Soph.

div1.head: δακνάζω
div1.sense: Dep. : metaph. to be afflicted, mournful, imperat. δακνάζου Aesch.

div1.head: δάκνω
div1.sense: to bite, of dogs, Il.; στόμιον δ. to champ the bit, Aesch.; χεῖλος ὀδοῦσι δακών, as a mark of determination, Tyrtae.; δ. ἑαυτόν to bite oneʼs lips for fear of laughing, Ar.
metaph. of pungent smoke and dust, to sting or prick the eyes, Ar.
of the mind, to bite or sting, δάκε φρένας μῦθος Il.; ἔδακε ἡ λύπη Hdt.; so in Trag.: —Pass., of love, δηχθεῖσα Eur.; καρδίαν δέδηγμαι I was stung, vexed at heart, Ar.

div1.head: δάκος
div1.sense: an animal of which the bite is dangerous, a noxious beast, Aesch.; δάκη θηρῶν ravenous beasts, Eur.

div1.head: δάκρυμα
div1.sense: that which is wept for, a subject for tears, Orac. ap. Hdt.
that which is wept, a tear, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: δακρυόεις
div1.sense: of persons, tearful, much-weeping, Hom.; δακρυόεν γελάσαι, as adv., to smile through tears, Il.
of things, tearful, causing tears, πόλεμος, μάχη Il.

div1.head: δάκρυον
div1.sense: a tear, Hom., Hdt., Attic, etc.
anything like tears, gum, Hdt.
= δάκρυμα Ι, Anth.

div1.head: δακρυπλώω
div1.sense: to swim with tears, of a drunkard, Od.

div1.head: δάκρυ
div1.sense: a tear, Lat. lacruma, Hom., Trag.
like δάκρυον, any drop, δ. πεύκινον Eur.

div1.head: δακρυρροέω
div1.sense: to melt into tears, shed tears, Soph.; ἐπί τινι at a thing, Eur.: of the eyes, to run with tears, Eur.

div1.head: δακρύρροος
div1.sense: flowing with tears, Eur.

div1.head: δακρυσίστακτος
div1.sense: dropping tears, Aesch.

div1.head: δακρυτός
div1.sense: wept over, tearful, Aesch., Anth.

div1.head: δακρυχαρής
div1.sense: delighting in tears, Anth.

div1.head: δακρυχέων
div1.sense: shedding tears, Hom., Aesch.; τινός for a person, Od.

div1.head: δακρυώδης
div1.sense: tearful, lamentable, Luc.

div1.head: δακρύω
div1.sense: intr. to weep, shed tears, Hom., etc.; c. acc. cogn., δ. γόους to lament with tears, Soph.: c. gen. causae, to weep for a thing, Eur.:—also, δ. βλέφαρα to flood them with tears, Eur.:—so perf. pass. to be tearful, be all in tears, Il.
of trees (cf. δάκρυον), Luc.
c. acc. to weep for, lament, Aesch., Soph., etc.:—Pass. to be wept for, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: δακτυλήθρα
div1.sense: a finger-sheath, Xen.

div1.head: δακτυλικός
div1.sense: set in a ring, Anth.

div1.head: δακτυλιογλυφία
div1.sense: the art of cutting gems (for rings), Plat.

div1.head: δακτυλιογλύφος
div1.sense: engraver of gems, Critias.

div1.head: δακτύλιος
div1.sense: a ring, seal-ring, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: δακτυλοδεικτέω
div1.sense: to point at with the finger, Dem.

div1.head: δακτυλόδεικτος
div1.sense: pointed at with the finger, Lat. digito monstratus, Aesch.

div1.head: δακτυλοκαμψόδυνος
div1.sense: wearying the fingers by keeping them bent, Anth.

div1.head: δάκτυλος
div1.sense: a finger, Lat. digitus, ἐπὶ δακτύλων συμβάλλεσθαι to reckon on the fingers, Hdt.; ὁ μέγας δ. the thumb, Hdt.
οἱ δ. τῶν ποδῶν the toes, Xen.; and δάκτυλος alone, like Lat. digitus, a toe, Ar.
the shortest Greek measure of length, a fingerʼs breadth, = about 7/10 of an inch, Hdt.
a metrical foot, dactyl, ¯ ˘ ˘, Plat.

div1.head: δακτυλότριπτος
div1.sense: worn by fingers, Anth.

div1.head: δαλός
div1.sense: a fire-brand, piece of blazing wood, Hom., Aesch.
a thunderbolt, Il.
a burnt-out torch: metaph. of an old man, Anth.

div1.head: δαμάζω
div1.sense: to overpower:
of animals, to tame, break in, to bring under the yoke: Mid. to do so for oneself, Hom., Xen.
of maidens, to make subject to a husband, Il.: Pass. to be forced or seduced, Hom.
to subdue or conquer, Hom.: Pass. to be subject to another, Hom.: (hence δμώς, δμωή).
to strike dead, kill, Od.
of wine and the like, to overcome, overpower, Hom.: Pass. to be overcome, δεδμημένοι ὕπνωι Il.; οἱ δμαθέντες the dead, Eur.

div1.head: δαμαλήβοτος
div1.sense: browsed by heifers, Anth.

div1.head: δαμάλης
div1.sense: a young steer, Anth.

div1.head: δαμαληφάγος
div1.sense: beef-eating, Anth.

div1.head: δαμαλίζω
div1.sense: poet. form of δαμάζω, to subdue, break in: Mid., Eur.

div1.head: δάμαλις
div1.sense: a heifer, Lat. juvenca, Aesch.
a girl, Anth.

div1.head: δάμαρ
div1.sense: a wife, spouse, Il., Trag.

div1.head: δαμασίμβροτος
div1.sense: taming mortals, man-slaying, Simon.

div1.head: δαμάτειρα
div1.sense: one who tames, Anth.

div1.head: δάμνημι
div1.sense: Il.:—Mid., Hom.:—Pass., ὑφʼ Ἕκτορι δάμνατο Il.

div1.head: δαμώματα
div1.sense: = τὰ δημοσίαι ἀιδόμενα, songs sung in public, Ar.

div1.head: Δαναΐδαι
div1.sense: the sons or descendants of Danaus, Eur.

div1.head: Δαναΐδες
div1.sense: daughters of Danaus.

div1.head: Δαναοί
div1.sense: the Danaans, subjects of Δάναος, king of Argos; in Il., for the Greeks generally.

div1.head: δανείζω
div1.sense: to put out money at usury, to lend, Plat., etc.
Mid. to have lent to one, to borrow, Ar.; ἐπὶ μεγάλοις τόκοις at high interest, Dem.
Pass., of the money, to be lent out, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: δάνειον
div1.sense: a loan, Dem.

div1.head: δάνεισμα
div1.sense: a loan, δ. ποιεῖσθαι δανείζεσθαι (in mid. sense), Thuc.

div1.head: δανεισμός
div1.sense: money-lending, Plat., etc.: metaph., αἵματος δανεισμός Eur.

div1.head: δανειστής
div1.sense: a money-lender, Plut., NTest.

div1.head: δανειστικός
div1.sense: of or for money-lending, Plut.

div1.head: δάνος
div1.sense: money lent, a loan, debt, Anth.

div1.head: δανός
div1.sense: burnt, dry, parched, Od.;Sup., δανότατος, Ar.

div1.head: δάος
div1.sense: a firebrand, torch, Hom.

div1.head: δαπανάω
div1.etym: some pass. tenses are also used in depon. sense, pres., imperf., aor1
div1.sense: to spend, Thuc., etc.; δαπ. εἴς τι to spend upon a thing, Thuc., Xen.; so also as Dep. to spend, Hdt.; ὅσα δεδαπάνησθε εἰς τὸν πόλεμον Dem.
to expend, consume, use up, Arist.:—metaph. of persons, ὑπὸ νόσου δαπανᾶσθαι Plut.
Causal, τὴν πόλιν δαπανᾶν to put it to expense, Thuc.

div1.head: δαπάνημα
div1.sense: money spent, Arist.: in pl. costs, expenses, Xen.

div1.head: δαπάνη
div1.sense: outgoing, cost, expense, expenditure, Hes.; χρημάτων Thuc.; δ. κούφη the cost is little, Eur.:—also in pl., Thuc.
money spent, ἵππων on horses, Pind.; δαπάνην παρέχειν money for spending, Hdt.
extravagance, Aeschin.

div1.head: δαπανηρός
div1.sense: of men, lavish, extravagant, Plat., Xen.
of things, expensive, Dem., Arist.:—adv. -ρῶς, Xen.

div1.head: δᾶ
div1.sense: explained by the Scholl. as Dor. for γῆ, in the phrases δᾶ φεῦ, φεῦ δᾶ Aesch., Eur.; οὐ δᾶν no by earth, Theocr. But it is prob. that δᾶ or Δᾶ is a Doric voc. of Δάν Ζάν (i. e. Ζήν Ζεύς), and Δᾶν acc. = Ζῆν (i. e. Ζῆνα).

div1.head: δα-
div1.sense: intensive Prefix, = ζα-, as in δά-σκιος, δα-φοινός.

div1.head: δάπεδον
div1.etym: prob. for ζάπεδον, i. e. διάπεδον.
div1.sense: any level surface: the floor of a chamber, Il., Hdt., Xen.; also, γῆς δάπεδον Ar.; and absol. the ground, Od.: pl. plains, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: δάπις
div1.sense: a carpet, rug, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: δάπτω
div1.sense: to devour, as wild beasts, Il.; of fire, Il.; of a spear, to rend, Il.: metaph., δάπτει τὸ μὴ ʼνδικον injustice gnaws the heart, Soph.; δάπτομαι κέαρ Aesch.

div1.head: Δαρδανίδης
div1.sense: a son or descendant of Dardanus, Il.

div1.head: Δαρδάνιος
div1.sense: Trojan, Il.

div1.head: Δαρδανίς
div1.sense: a Trojan woman, Il.

div1.head: Δάρδανος
div1.sense: Dardanus, son of Zeus, founder of Troy, Il.:—as adj., Δάρδανος ἀνήρ a Trojan, Il.

div1.head: δαρδάπτω
div1.sense: Il.: κτήματα δαρδάπτουσιν they devour oneʼs patrimony, Od.

div1.head: Δαρεικός
div1.sense: Δᾱρεικὸς στατήρ or Δαρεικός, alone, a Persian gold coin, a Daric, Hdt., etc. These are said to have been first coined by Darius Hystaspes.

div1.head: Δαρειογενής
div1.sense: born from Darius, Aesch.

div1.head: Δαρεῖος
div1.sense: Darius, name of several kings of Persia; being a Greek form of Persian dara, a king.

div1.head: δαρθάνω
div1.sense: to sleep, Od.

div1.head: δάσκιος
div1.sense: thick-shaded, bushy, Od., Eur.; of a beard, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: δάσμευσις
div1.sense: a distributing, Xen.

div1.head: δασμολογέω
div1.sense: to collect as tribute, τι παρά τινος Dem.:—c. acc. pers. exact tribute from him, Isocr.

div1.head: δασμολογία
div1.sense: collection of tribute, Plut.

div1.head: δασμολόγος
div1.sense: a tax-gatherer, Strab.

div1.head: δασμός
div1.sense: a division, distribution, sharing of spoil, Il., Hhymn.
in Attic an impost, tribute, ἀοιδοῦ δ. tribute paid to her, Soph.; δασμὸν τίνειν Soph.; δασμὸν φέρειν, ἀποφέρειν, ἀποδιδόναι Xen.

div1.head: δασμοφορέω
div1.sense: to be subject to tribute, Aesch.: —Pass., δασμοφορεῖταί τινι tribute is paid one, Xen.

div1.head: δασμοφόρος
div1.sense: paying tribute, tributary, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: δασπλῆτις
div1.etym: Perh. from δα, πλήσσω, ς being inserted.
div1.sense: horrid, frightful, Ἐρινύς Od.; of Hecate, Theocr.

div1.head: δασύθριξ
div1.sense: thick-haired, hairy, Anth.

div1.head: δασύκερκος
div1.sense: bushy-tailed, ἀλώπηξ Theocr.

div1.head: δασύκνημος
div1.sense: shaggy-legged, of Pan, Anth.

div1.head: δασύμαλλος
div1.sense: thick-fleeced, woolly, Od., Eur.

div1.head: δασύπους
div1.sense: rough-foot, i. e. a hare, Arist.; λαγωὸς ὁ δ. Babr.

div1.head: δασύς
div1.sense: opp. to ψιλός in all senses:
thick with hair, hairy, shaggy, rough, Od.; of young hares, downy, Hdt.

thick with leaves, Od.; θρίδαξ δασέα a lettuce with all the leaves on, Hdt.:—of places, thick with bushes or wood, Od.; διὰ τῶν δασέων through the copses, Ar.; δ. ὕληι thick with copse-wood, Hdt., etc.; rarely c. gen., δασὺς δένδρων Xen.:— τὸ δασύ bushy country, Xen.

div1.head: δασύστερνος
div1.sense: shaggy-breasted, Hes.

div1.head: δασυχαίτης
div1.sense: shaggy-haired, Anth.

div1.head: δατέομαι
div1.sense: to divide among themselves, τὰ μὲν εὖ δάσσαντο μετὰ σφισίν Il.; ἄνδιχα πάντα δάσασθαι Hom.; μένος Ἄρηος δατέονται they share, i. e. are alike filled with, the spirit of Ares, Il.; of persons at a banquet, κρέα δατεῦντο Od.; διδόναι τινα κυσὶ δάσασθαι to tear in pieces, Il.
[ἡμίονοι χθόνα ποσσὶ δατεῦντο measured the ground with their feet, Lat. carpebant viam pedibus, Il.
to cut in two, Il.
simply, to divide, to divide or give to others, Hdt.:—perf. in pass. sense, to be divided, Il., Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: δατήριος
div1.sense: dividing, distributing, Aesch.

div1.head: δατητής
div1.sense: a distributer, Aesch.

div1.head: Δαυλία
div1.sense: sc. Δαυλία χώρα Phocis, Soph.

div1.head: Δαυλιάς
div1.sense: a woman of Daulis, epith. of Philomela, who was changed into the nightingale, Thuc.

div1.head: Δαύλιος
div1.sense: a Daulian, Hdt.

div1.head: Δαυλίς
div1.sense: Daulis, a city of Phocis, Hom., etc.

div1.head: δάφνη
div1.sense: the laurel, or rather the bay-tree, Lat. laurus, Od., Hes., etc.; sacred to Apollo, who delivered his oracles ἐκ δάφνης, Hhymn.

div1.head: δαφνηφορέω
div1.sense: to bear a laurel crown, Plut.

div1.head: δαφνηφόρος
div1.sense: laurel-bearing, δ. κλῶνες laurel branches borne in worship of Apollo, Eur.

div1.head: δαφνιακός
div1.sense: belonging to a laurel, Anth.

div1.head: δαφνογηθής
div1.sense: delighting in laurel, Anth.

div1.head: δαφνόκομος
div1.sense: laurel-crowned, Anth.

div1.head: δαφνώδης
div1.sense: like laurel: laurelled, Eur.

div1.head: δαφοινός
div1.sense: of savage animals, blood-red, tawny, δαφοινὸν δέρμα λέοντος Il.; δράκων ἐπὶ νῶτα δαφοινός Il.: the form δαφοινεός bears the same sense, εἷμα δαφοινεὸν αἵματι red with blood, Il.; δαφοινὸς ἀετός Aesch., etc.
metaph. savage, cruel, Hhymn., Aesch.

div1.head: δαψιλής
div1.sense: abundant, plentiful, Hdt.:— adv. -έως, in abundance, Theocr.
of persons, liberal, profuse, Plut.:—Sup. adv., δαψιλέστατα ζῆν Xen.

div1.head: δάω
div1.sense: an old Root, δα to learn, Lat. disco, which becomes Causal, to teach, Lat. doceo, in redupl. aor2 δέδαε and in διδάσκω:

to learn, and in perf., to know; c. gen. pers. to learn from one, Od.; c. gen. rei, to hear tidings of a thing, Il. From δέδαα again is formed a pres. mid. inf. δεδάασθαι, to search out, c. acc., Od.—The pres. in this sense is διδάσκομαι.
Causal, in redupl. aor. 2 δέδαον, c. dupl. acc. to teach a person a thing, Od.; c. inf. to teach one to do a thing, Od.—The pres. in this sense is διδάσκω.

div1.head: δέατο
div1.sense: a word of doubtful origin, expl. by ἐδόκει, ἀεικέλιος δέατʼ εἶναι he seemed, methought he was, a pitiful fellow, Od.:

div1.head: δεδίσκομαι
div1.sense: to greet, Od.

div1.head: δεδοκημένος
div1.sense: irreg. partic. of δέχομαι (Ionic δέχομαι), in act. sense, waiting, lying in wait, Il., Hes.;—not to be confounded with Attic δεδόκημαι from δοκέω.

div1.head: δέελος
div1.sense: resolved form of δῆλος, Il.

div1.head: δέημα
div1.sense: an entreaty, Ar.

div1.head: δέησις
div1.sense: an entreating, asking: a prayer, entreaty, Dem., NTest.

div1.head: δεητικός
div1.sense: suppliant, Plut.

div1.head: δεῖγμα
div1.sense: a sample, pattern, proof, specimen, Lat. documentum, Eur., Ar., etc.; δείγματος ἕνεκα by way of sample, Dem.
a place in the Peiraeeus, where merchants set out their wares for sale, a bazaar, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: δειγματίζω
div1.sense: to make a show of, NTest.

div1.head: δειδήμων
div1.sense: fearful, cowardly, Il.

div1.head: δειδίσκομαι
div1.etym: Dep., only in pres. and imperf.
div1.sense: to meet with outstretched hand, to greet, welcome, δεξιτερῆι δειδίσκετο χειρί Od.; δέπαϊ δειδίσκετο pledged him in a cup, Od.; also, δεδισκόμενος Od.
= δείκνυμι 1, to show, Hhymn.

div1.head: δειδίσσομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:—Causal of δείδω, to frighten, alarm, μὴ δειδίσσεο λαὸν Ἀχαιῶν Il.; Ἕκτορα ἀπὸ νεκροῦ δειδίξασθαι to scare him from the corpse, Il.; οὔ σε ἔοικε δειδίσσεσθαι it beseems not to attempt to frighten thee, Il.:—c. inf., φευγέμεν δειδίσσετο Theocr.:—in Attic form, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: δείδω
div1.etym: pres. δείδω only in first pers., δέδοικα or δέδια being always used as pres. in Attic.
div1.sense: to fear, absol., Hom., etc.; foll. by a prep., δ. περί τινι to be alarmed, anxious about . . , Il., Attic; ἀμφί τινι, περί τινος, ὑπέρ τινος Il.:—followed by a relat. clause with μή . . , Lat. vereor ne . . , I fear it is . . , followed by subj.; rarely by ind., δείδω μὴ νημερτέα εἶπεν Od.; δ. μὴ οὐ . . , Lat. vereor ut . . , I fear it is not . . , foll. by subj., Hdt., etc.
c. inf. to fear to do, Il., Thuc.
c. acc. to fear, dread, Hom., etc.
τὸ δεδιός, oneʼs fearing, = δέος, Thuc.

div1.head: δειελιάω
div1.sense: to wait till evening, σὺ δʼ ἔρχεο δειελιήσας Od.

div1.head: δειελινός
div1.sense: at evening, Theocr.

div1.head: δείελος
div1.sense: of or belonging to evening, δείελον ἦμαρ eventide, Od., Theocr.
as Subst. (sub. χρόνος), late evening, εἰσόκεν ἔλθηι δείελος Il.

div1.head: δεικανάω
div1.sense: to point out, shew, in Ionic imperf. δεικανάασκεν Theocr.
Hom. uses it only in Mid. = δειδίσκομαι, to salute, greet, δεικανόωντʼ ἐπέεσσιν Od.; δεικανόωντο δέπασσι pledged him, Il.

div1.head: δεικηλίκτας
div1.sense: Lacon. for ὑποκριτής, Lat. mimus, a burlesque actor, Plut.

div1.head: δείκηλον
div1.sense: a representation, exhibition, Hdt.

div1.head: δείκνυμι
div1.sense: to bring to light, display, exhibit, Od., etc.:—Mid. to set before one, Il.
to shew, point out, Il., Soph.:—absol., αὐτὸ δείξει experiment will shew, Plat.; so, δείξει alone, Ar.
to point out by words, to tell, explain, teach, Lat. indicare, ὁδόν Od., etc.:— to shew, prove, with part., ἔδειξαν ἕτοιμοι ὄντες shewed that they were ready, Thuc.
of accusers, to inform against, τινά Ar.
to offer, proffer, τὰ πιστά Aesch.: to cause, πήματα Aesch.

in Mid., like δειδίσκομαι, δεξιόομαι, to welcome, greet, τὼ καὶ δεικνύμενος προσέφη Hom.: —so also in perf. and plup. pass., δείδεκτʼ Ἀχιλῆα he pledged him, drank to him, Il.; τοὺς μὲν κυπέλλοις δειδέχατο Il.; δειδέχαται μύθοισι Od.

div1.head: δεικτέος
div1.sense: to be shown, Xen.
δεικτέον μοι it is my duty to show, Dem.

div1.head: δειλαίνω
div1.sense: to be a coward or cowardly, Arist.

div1.head: δείλαιος
div1.sense: lengthd. form of δειλός, wretched, sorry, paltry, mostly of persons, Trag.; also, δ. χάρις a sorry kindness, Aesch.; δ. σποδός paltry dust, Soph., etc. [Penult. is often made short in Attic Poets.]

div1.head: δειλακρίων
div1.sense: a coward: commonly with a coaxing sense, poor fellow! Ar.

div1.head: δείλακρος
div1.sense: very pitiable, Ar.

div1.head: δείλη
div1.sense: afternoon, ἔσσεται ἢ ἠὼς ἢ δείλη ἢ μέσον ἦμαρ Il.; divided into early and late (πρωΐα and ὀψία) , περὶ δείλην πρωΐην, or δείλης ὀψίης Hdt.; τῆς δείλης in the course of the afternoon, Xen.
the late afternoon, evening, Xen.

div1.head: δειλία
div1.sense: cowardice, Hdt., Soph.; δειλίην ὀφλεῖν to be charged with cowardice, Hdt.

div1.head: δειλίασις
div1.sense: fright, faintheartedness, Plut.

div1.head: δειλιάω
div1.sense: to be afraid.

div1.head: δείλομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to verge towards afternoon, δείλετό τʼ ἠέλιος Od.

div1.head: δειλός
div1.sense: of persons, cowardly, craven, Il.; hence, vile, worthless, Il.:— δειλός τινος afraid of . . , Anth.
miserable, luckless, wretched, Hom.; with a compassionate sense, like Lat. miser, δειλοὶ βροτοί poor mortals! ἆ δειλέ poor wretch! ἆ δειλοί poor wretches! Hom.
of things, miserable, wretched, Hes., Soph.

div1.head: δειμαίνω
div1.sense: to be afraid, in a fright, Hhymn., Hdt., etc.
c. acc. to fear a thing, Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: δειμαλέος
div1.sense: timid, Mosch.
horrible, fearful, Batr., Theogn.

div1.head: δεῖμα
div1.sense: fear, affright, Il., Hdt., Attic
an object of fear, a terror, horror, ὦ πῦρ σὺ καὶ πᾶν δ. Soph.: esp. in pl., δειμάτων ἄχη fearful plagues or monsters, Aesch.; δείματα θηρῶν Eur.

div1.head: δειματόεις
div1.sense: frightened, scared, Anth.

div1.head: δειματόω
div1.sense: to frighten, Hdt., Ar.:— Pass. to be frightened, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: δειμός
div1.sense: fear, terror:— personified Δεῖμος, Il.
contr. for δέον neut. part., v. δεῖ ΙΙΙ.

div1.head: δεῖνα
div1.sense: such an one, a certain one, whom one cannot or will not name, ὁ δεῖνα Ar., etc.; ὁ δεῖνα τοῦ δεῖνος τὸν δεῖνα εἰσαγγέλλει Dem.
δεῖνα in Com. as an interjection, Lat. malum! plague onʼt! Ar.

div1.head: δεινοθέτης
div1.sense: a knave, Mosch.

div1.head: δεινολογέομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to complain loudly, Hdt.

div1.head: δεινοπαθέω
div1.sense: to complain loudly of sufferings, Dem.

div1.head: δεινόπους
div1.sense: terrible of foot, Ἀρὰ δ. (as if she was a hound upon the track), Soph.

div1.head: δεινός
div1.etym: from δέος, properly δεεινός, cf. ἐλεεινός, ἐλεινός, from ἔλεος
div1.sense: fearful, terrible, dread, dire, Hom., etc.; δεινὸν ἀϋτεῖν, βροντᾶν to shout, thunder terribly, Il.; δεινὸν δέρκεσθαι, παπταίνειν, ἰδεῖν to look terrible, Hom.; but, δεινὸς ἰδέσθαι fearful to behold, Od.; δεινὸς μὲν ὁρᾶν, δεινὸς δὲ κλύειν Soph.:— τὸ δεινόν danger, suffering, awe, terror, Hdt., Aesch., etc.; so, τὰ δεινά Soph., etc.:— οὐδὲν δεινοί, μὴ ἀποστέωσιν no fear of their revolting, Hdt.:— δεινὸν ποιεῖσθαι to take ill, complain of, be indignant at a thing, Lat. aegre ferre, Hdt., etc.; δεινὰ παθεῖν to suffer dreadful, illegal, arbitrary treatment, Attic; so in adv., δεινῶς φέρειν Hdt.; δ. ἔχειν to be in straits, Xen.
with a notion of Force or Power, mighty, powerful, δεινὸν σάκος the mighty shield, Il.

simply, wondrous, marvellous, strange, τὸ συγγενές τοι δεινόν kin has a strange power, Aesch.; δ. ἵμερος, ἔρως, δέος Hdt.; δεινὸν ἂν εἴη, εἰ . . , it were strange that . . , Eur.:—adv. -νῶς, marvellously, exceedingly, δ. μέλας, ἄνυδρος Hdt.

the sense of powerful, wondrous passed into that of able, clever, skilful, Hdt., Attic; esp. of practical ability, opp. to σοφός, Plat.: c. inf., δεινὸς εὑρεῖν clever at inventing, Aesch.; δεινὸς λέγειν Soph.; δεινὸς πράγμασι χρῆσθαι Dem.: also c. acc., δεινὸς τὴν τέχνην Plat.; δ. περί τι or τινος Plat.

div1.head: δεινότης
div1.sense: terribleness, Thuc.: harshness, sternness, severity, νόμων Thuc.
natural ability, cleverness, shrewdness, Dem.; esp. in an orator, Thuc., Dem.

div1.head: δεινόω
div1.sense: to make terrible: to exaggerate, Thuc.

div1.head: δείνωσις
div1.sense: exaggeration, Plat.

div1.head: δεινώψ
div1.sense: fierce-eyed, of the Erinyes, Soph.

div1.head: δειπνέω
div1.sense: to make a meal, Hom.: in Attic to take the chief meal, to dine, δ. τὸ ἄριστον to make breakfast serve as dinner, Xen.
c. acc., δ. ἄρτον to make a meal on bread, Hes.; also, δ. ἀπό τινος Ar.

div1.head: δείπνηστος
div1.sense: meal-time, Od.

div1.head: δειπνητήριον
div1.sense: a dining-room, Plut.

div1.head: δειπνητικός
div1.sense: of or for cookery: adv. -κῶς, like a cook, artistically, Ar.

div1.head: δειπνίζω
div1.sense: to entertain at dinner, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: δειπνολόχος
div1.sense: fishing for invitations to dinner, parasitic, Hes.

div1.head: δεῖπνον
div1.sense: in Hom. the principal meal of the day, —sometimes the noonday meal, sometimes = ἄριστον, the morning meal, sometimes = δόρπον, the evening meal. In old Attic the midday or afternoon meal, dinner or supper:— ἀπὸ δείπνου straightway after the meal, Il.; καλεῖν ἐπὶ δεῖπνον; δ. παραθεῖναι, etc.
generally, fodder, provender, Il., Aesch.

div1.head: δειπνοποιέω
div1.sense: to give a dinner:— Mid. to dine, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: δειπνοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying meat-offerings, Plut.

div1.head: δεῖ
div1.sense: c. acc. pers. et inf., δεῖ τινὰ ποιῆσαι it is binding on one to do a thing, one must, one ought, Lat. oportet, Hom., etc.:—rarely, δεῖ σε ὅπως δείξεις δεῖ σε δεῖξαι, Soph.: —rarely also c. dat. pers. et inf., there is need for one to do, δεῖ τινὶ ποιήσαι Eur., Xen.
c. acc. rei et inf., δεῖ τι γενέσθαι Thuc., etc.:—for the phrase οἴομαι δεῖν, v. οἴομαι:— when used absol., an inf. may be supplied, μὴ πεῖθʼ ἃ μὴ δεῖ (sc. πείθειν) Soph., etc.

(from δέω, to want), c. gen. rei, there is need of, there is wanting, Lat. opus est re, οὐδὲν δεῖ τινός Hdt., Attic:—phrases, πολλοῦ δεῖ there wants much, far from it; ὀλίγου δεῖ there wants little, all but:— in answers, πολλοῦ γε δεῖ, πολλοῦ γε καὶ δεῖ far from it, Ar., Dem.; πλεῦνος δεῖ it is still further from it, Hdt:— ὀλίγου δεῖν absol., in same sense, Plat.; μικροῦ δεῖν Dem.
with a dat. pers. added, δεῖ μοί τινος, Lat. opus est mihi re, Aesch., Thuc., etc.
with acc. pers. added, δεῖ σε προμηθέως Aesch.

neut. part. δέον, contr. δεῖν, absol., like ἐξόν, παρόν it being needful, quum oporteret, Plat.; οὐκ ἀπήντα, δέον, he did not appear in court, though he ought to have done so, Dem.; so, οὐδὲν δέον there being no need, Hdt.
for δέον, τό, as Subst., v. sub voce.

div1.head: δειράς
div1.sense: the ridge of a chain of hills, Hom., Soph.:—in pl., Soph., Eur.

div1.head: δειραχθής
div1.sense: heavy on the neck, Anth.

div1.head: δειρή
div1.etym: note that we get δέρη not δέρα, even in Attic.
div1.sense: the neck, throat, Il., Hdt.; Attic Trag.

div1.head: δειροτομέω
div1.sense: to cut the throat of a person, behead, σὺ δʼ ἄμφω δειροτομήσεις Hom.

div1.head: δεισήνωρ
div1.sense: fearing man, Aesch.

div1.head: δεισιδαιμονία
div1.sense: fear of the gods, religious feeling, Polyb.: in bad sense, superstition, Theophr.

div1.head: δεισιδαίμων
div1.sense: fearing the gods:
in good sense, like εὐσεβής, pious, religious, Xen.
in bad sense, superstitious, bigoted, Theophr.—comp. -έστερος, somewhat superstitious, NTest.

div1.head: δεκάβοιος
div1.sense: worth ten oxen, τὸ δεκάβοιον a coin attributed to Theseus, Plut.

div1.head: δεκαγονία
div1.sense: the tenth generation, Luc.

div1.head: δεκαδαρχία
div1.sense: the government of the ten, Isocr.

div1.head: δεκάδαρχος
div1.sense: a commander of ten, Lat. decurio, Xen.

div1.head: δεκαδεύς
div1.sense: one of a decury, Xen.

div1.head: δεκάδωρος
div1.sense: ten palms long or broad, Hes.

div1.head: δεκαέτηρος
div1.sense: ten-yearly, Plat.

div1.head: δεκαετής
div1.sense: ten years old, Hdt.
of or lasting ten years, πόλεμος Thuc.

div1.head: δεκάζω
div1.sense: to bribe or corrupt judges, Isocr., Aeschin.:—Pass. to be bribed, Plut.

div1.head: δεκάκις
div1.sense: ten-times, Il.

div1.head: δεκάκλινος
div1.sense: holding ten dinner-couches, Xen.

div1.head: δεκακυμία
div1.sense: the tenth, i.e. overwhelming, wave, Lat. fluctus decumanus, Luc.: cf. τρικυμία.

div1.head: δεκάμηνος
div1.sense: ten months old, Xen.
in the tenth month, Hdt.

div1.head: δεκάμνους
div1.sense: weighing or worth ten minae, Ar.

div1.head: δεκάμφορος
div1.sense: holding ten ἀμφορεῖς (about 90 gallons), Eur.

div1.head: δεκάπαλαι
div1.sense: very long ago, like δωδεκάπαλαι, Ar.

div1.head: δεκάπηχυς
div1.sense: ten cubits long, Hdt.

div1.head: δεκαπλάσιος
div1.sense: tenfold, Lat. decuplus, Plat.:— ἡ δεκαπλασία (sc. τιμή) a fine of ten times the amount, Dem.

div1.head: δεκάπλεθρος
div1.sense: enclosing ten πλέθρα, Thuc.

div1.head: δεκάπολις
div1.sense: a ten-city land, Decapolis, NTest.

div1.head: δέκα
div1.etym: Some connect it with δάκτυλος, from the number of the fingers.
div1.sense: ten, Lat. decem, Hom., etc.: —οἱ δέκα the Ten, Oratt.: οἱ δέκα ἔτη ἀφʼ ἥβης those who are ten years past 20 (the age of military service), Xen.

div1.head: δεκαρχία
div1.sense: the government of ten, Xen.

div1.head: δεκασμός
div1.sense: bribery, Plut.

div1.head: δεκάσπορος
div1.sense: a lapse of ten seed-times, i. e. ten years, Eur.

div1.head: δεκάς
div1.sense: a decad: a company of ten, Lat. decuria, Il., Hdt.
a bribed company of ten.
the number ten, Arist.

div1.head: δεκαταῖος
div1.sense: on the tenth day, Plat.
ten days old, Luc.

div1.head: δεκατάλαντος
div1.sense: worth ten talents: δίκη δεκ. an action in which the damages were laid at ten talents, Aeschin.

div1.head: δεκατευτήριον
div1.sense: the tenths-office, custom-house, Xen.

div1.head: δεκατεύω
div1.sense: to exact the tenth part from a man, to make him pay tithe, τούτους δεκατεῦσαι τῶι θεῶι to make them pay a tithe to the god, Hdt.:— also of things, δ. τὰ ἐξ ἀγροῦ ὡραῖα to tithe them (as an offering), Xen.: and so, Pass., δεκατευθῆναι τῶι Διΐ Hdt.: hence proverb., ἐλπὶς ἦν δεκατευθῆναι τὰς Θήβας, i. e. that it would be made to pay tithe, Xen.

div1.head: δεκατηλόγος
div1.sense: a tithe-collector, Dem.

div1.head: δεκάτη
div1.sense: v. δέκατος II.

div1.head: δεκατόσπορος
div1.sense: in the tenth generation, Anth.

div1.head: δέκατος
div1.sense: tenth, Hom., etc.
δεκάτη, sc. μερίς the tenth part, tithe, Hdt., etc.
δεκάτη (sc. ἡμέρα), the tenth day, Hom.; at Athens, the tenth day after birth, when the child has a name given it, τὴν δ. θύειν to give a naming-day feast, Ar.; τὴν δ. ἑστιᾶσαι ὑπὲρ τοῦ υἱοῦ Dem.

div1.head: δεκατόω
div1.sense: like δεκατεύω, to take tithe of a person, τινα NTest.: Pass. to pay tithe, NTest.

div1.head: δεκάφυλος
div1.sense: consisting of ten tribes, Hdt.

div1.head: δεκάχαλκον
div1.sense: the denarius, = ten χαλκοῖ, Plut.

div1.head: δεκάχιλοι
div1.sense: ten thousand, Il.; cf. ἐννεάχιλοι.

div1.head: Δεκελεῆθεν
div1.sense: from Deceleia, Thuc.

div1.head: Δεκέλεια
div1.sense: Deceleia , a place in Attica, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: Δεκελεύς
div1.sense: a Decelean, Thuc.

div1.head: δεκέτης
div1.sense: lasting ten years, Soph., Plat.
ten years old, Eur.: fem. δεκέτις, ιδος, Plat.

div1.head: δεκτέος
div1.sense: to be received, Luc.

div1.head: δέκτης
div1.sense: a receiver: a beggar, Od.

div1.head: δεκτός
div1.sense: acceptable, NTest.

div1.head: δέκτωρ
div1.sense: one who takes upon himself or on his own head, αἵματος δ. νέου Aesch.

div1.head: δεκώρυγος
div1.sense: ten fathoms long, Xen.

div1.head: δελεάζω
div1.sense: to entice or catch by a bait: — Pass., Xen., Dem.
c. acc. cogn., νῶτον ὑὸς περὶ ἄγκιστρον δ. to put it on the hook as a bait, Hdt.

div1.head: δελεάρπαξ
div1.sense: snapping at the bait, Anth.

div1.head: δέλεαρ
div1.sense: a bait, Xen.: metaph., δ. τινος bait for a person, Eur.

div1.head: δέλτα
div1.sense: indecl., fourth letter of the Gr. alph.: as numeral, δʼ = τέσσαρες and τέταρτος, but ,δ .
δ is the medial dental mute, between the tenuis τ and the aspirate θ.
changes of δ in the dialects:
Aeolic into β, as σάμβαλον for σάνδαλον:— reversely, ὀβελός becomes ὀδελός in Doric
Aeolic or Doric into ζ, or ζ into δ and σδ, v. ζῆτα II. 2
into θ, as ψεῦδος ψύθος.
into λ, as δαήρ, Lat. levir, δάκρυ lacryma, δασύς λάσιος.
into ς, as ὀδμή ὀσμή, ἴδμεν ἴσμεν.
sometimes δ is inserted to give a fuller sound, (ἀνήρ) ἀνέρος ἀνδρός.
δ is sometimes lost, cf. διωγμός, δίωξις with ἰωκή.
it sometimes represents j. (y), as in ἤδη or δή, Lat. jam.

div1.head: δέλτα
div1.sense: anything shaped like a Δ, a name for islands formed by the mouths of large rivers, as the Nile, Hdt.

div1.head: δελτογράφος
div1.sense: writing on a tablet, recording, Aesch.

div1.head: δέλτος
div1.sense: a writing-tablet, from the letter Δ (the old shape of tablets), Hdt., Trag.: metaph., δέλτοις φρενῶν on the tablets of the heart, Aesch.

div1.head: δελφακόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to grow up to pighood, Ar.

div1.head: δέλφαξ
div1.sense: a young pig, porker, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Δελφικός
div1.sense: Delphic, Aesch.

div1.head: Δελφίνιον
div1.sense: a temple of Apollo at Athens, τὸ ἐπὶ Δελφινίωι δικαστήριον the law-court there, Plut.

div1.head: δέλφιξ
div1.sense: a tripod, Plut.

div1.head: δελφίς
div1.sense: the dolphin, Hom., etc.

a mass of lead, prob. shaped like a dolphin, hung at the yard-arm, and suddenly let down on the decks of the enemyʼs ships, Ar.:—hence, κεραῖαι δελφινοφόροι beams with pulleys to let down the δελφίς, Thuc.

div1.head: Δελφοί
div1.sense: Delphi, a famous oracle of Apollo in Phocis at the foot of Parnassus (called Pytho by Hom. and Hdt.), Hhymn., Soph.
the Delphians, Hdt.

div1.head: Δελφός
div1.sense: king of Delphi, Aesch.

div1.head: δελφύς
div1.sense: the womb, Arist.

div1.head: δέμας
div1.sense: the frame of man, the body, Hom.; rarely of other animals, Od.; properly the living body. — Hom. uses it only in acc. sg., absol., μικρὸς δέμας small in stature; ἄριστος δέμας, δέμας ἀθανάτοισι ἔοικε, etc.
in Trag. as a periphrasis, like κάρα, κτανεῖν μητρῷον δ. Aesch.; Ἡράκλειον δ. Eur.; Δαματρὸς ἀκτᾶς δ., i. e. bread, Eur.
as adv., δέμας πυρὸς αἰθομένοιο in form or fashion like burning fire, Lat. instar ignis, Il.

div1.head: δέμνιον
div1.sense: mostly in pl. δέμνια, the bedstead or matrass, Hom.
generally, a bed, bedding, Od., etc.

div1.head: δεμνιοτήρης
div1.sense: keeping one to oneʼs bed, μοῖρα δ. a lingering fate, Aesch.

div1.head: δέμω
div1.sense: to build, Il., etc.:—Mid., ἐδείματο οἴκους he built him houses, Od.:—generally, to construct, δ. ἀλωήν Hhymn.; δ. ὁδόν, ἁμαξιτόν, Lat. munire viam, Hdt.

div1.head: δενδίλλω
div1.sense: to turn the eyes or glance quickly, δενδίλλων ἐς ἕκαστον Il.

div1.head: δένδρεον
div1.sense: a tree, mostly in pl., Hom., Hes., Hdt.

div1.head: δενδρήεις
div1.sense: woody, Od.

div1.head: δενδριακός
div1.sense: of a tree, Anth.

div1.head: δενδροβατέω
div1.sense: to climb trees, Anth.

div1.head: δενδροκόμης
div1.sense: of a woodman, Anth.

div1.head: δενδρόκομος
div1.sense: grown with wood, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: δενδροκοπέω
div1.sense: to cut down trees, esp. vines and fruit-trees, Xen.; δ. χώραν to waste a country by cutting down the trees, ap. Dem.

div1.head: δένδρον
div1.etym: for forms such as δενδρέων cf. δένδρεον
div1.sense: a tree, Ar.; δένδρα fruit-trees (opp. to ὕλη timber), Thuc., etc.

div1.head: δενδροπήμων
div1.sense: blasting trees, Aesch.

div1.head: δενδροτομέω
div1.sense: to lay waste a country, Thuc.: metaph., δ. τὰ νῶτα Ar.

div1.head: δενδροφόρος
div1.sense: bearing trees; Sup. -ώτατος, Plut.

div1.head: δενδρόφυτος
div1.sense: planted with trees, Plut.

div1.head: δενδρώδης
div1.sense: tree-like: δενδρ. Νύμφαι wood-nymphs, Anth.

div1.head: δενδρῶτις
div1.sense: fem. adj. wooded, Eur.

div1.head: δεννάζω
div1.sense: to abuse, revile, τινά Theogn., Soph.; c. acc. cogn., κακὰ ῥήματα δεννάζειν to utter words of foul reproach, Soph.

div1.head: δέννος
div1.sense: a reproach, disgrace, Hdt.

div1.head: δεξαμενή
div1.etym: aor1 part. fem. of δέχομαι, with changed accent
div1.sense: a reservoir, tank, cistern, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: δεξιά
div1.sense: the right hand, opp. to ἀριστερά, Il.; ἐκ δεξιᾶς on the right, Ar.; ἐν δεξιᾶι ἔχειν τὰ οὔρεα to keep them on the right, as you go, Hdt.; ἐν δ. λαβεῖν τὴν Σικελίαν Hdt.; so, ἐν δ. ἐσπλέοντι on your right as you sail in, Hdt.; used in welcoming, δεξιὰν διδόναι to salute by offering the right hand, Ar.

the right hand given as a pledge or assurance, δεξιαὶ ἧις ἐπέπιθμεν Il.; δεξιὰς δόντες καὶ λαβόντες having exchanged assurances, made a treaty, Xen.; δεξιὰς παρὰ βασιλέως φέρειν μή . . to bring pledges that he would not . . , Xen.—Though δεξιά is manifestly fem. of δεξιός, it is always used as a Subst. without χείρ; but δ. χείρ occurs in Soph., Eur., Ar.

div1.head: δεξίμηλος
div1.sense: receiving sheep, i. e. rich in sacrifices, Eur.

div1.head: δεξιολάβος
div1.sense: a spearman: in pl. guards, NTest.: others δεξιοβόλοι javelin-men.

div1.head: δεξιόομαι
div1.sense: to greet with the right hand, welcome, greet (cf. δείκνυμι II), c. acc. pers., Ar., Xen.; c. dat. pers., δεξιοῦσθαι θεοῖς to raise oneʼs right hand to the gods, pay honour to them, Aesch.; c. acc. rei, ἄμυστιν δεξιούμενοι pledging one in a bumper, Eur.:—Plat. has aor1 δεξιωθῆναι in pass. sense.

div1.head: δεξιόσειρος
div1.sense: harnessed by a trace on the right side, of a third horse which was outside the regular pair:— hence, generally, spirited, impetuous, Soph.

div1.head: δεξιός
div1.sense: on the right hand or side, Lat. dexter, opp. to ἀριστερός, Hom., etc.; τὸ δ. (sc. κέρας) the right of an army, Xen.:—adverb. usages, ἐπὶ δεξιά on the right, Il.; ἐπὶ δεξιόφιν (Epic gen.) towards the right, Il.; πρὸς δεξιά Hdt.

fortunate, boding good, of the flight of birds, δεξιὸς ὄρνις, αἴσιος, Hom. —This sense came from the Greek augurs looking to the North, so that lucky omens, which came from the East, were on the right, while the unlucky ones from the West were on the left.
metaph. dexterous, ready, opp. to σκαιός (sinister, French gauche); and of the mind, sharp, shrewd, clever, Ar., Thuc., etc.:—adv., δεξιῶς; Sup. δεξιώτατα, Ar.

div1.head: δεξιότης
div1.sense: dexterity, cleverness, Hdt., Ar.; opp. to ἀμαθία, Thuc.

div1.head: δεξίπυρος
div1.sense: receiving fire, Eur.

div1.head: δεξιτερός
div1.sense: right, the right, Hom.: δεξιτερή, like δεξιά (sub. χείρ), the right hand, Il.; Epic dat. δεξιτερῆιφι Il.

div1.head: δεξίωμα
div1.sense: a pledge of friendship, Soph.

div1.head: δεξίωσις
div1.sense: a greeting, canvassing, Lat. ambitus, Plut.

div1.head: δέον
div1.etym: neut. part. of the impers. δεῖ, made into a Noun
div1.sense: that which is binding, needful, right, proper, Soph., Xen.; τὰ δέοντα things needful or proper, advantages or duties, Thuc., etc.; ἐν δέοντι (sc. καιρῶι), in good time, Lat. opportune, Eur.; ἐν τῶι δέοντι Hdt.; εἰς τὸ δέον for a needful purpose, Hdt.; hence (at Athens) the phrase for secret service, εἰς τὸ δέον ἀπώλεσα Ar.

div1.head: δέος
div1.sense: fear, alarm, affright, Hom., etc.; τεθνάναι τῶι δέει τινά to be dead afraid of a person, Dem.
awe, reverence, Aesch.
reason for fear, Il.: a means of inspiring fear, Thuc.

div1.head: δέπας
div1.sense: a beaker, goblet, chalice, Hom.

div1.head: -δε
div1.sense: enclitic Particle, joined,

to names of Places in the acc., to denote motion towards that place, οἶκόνδε (Attic οἴκαδε) home- wards, ἅλαδε sea- wards, Οὐλυμπόνδε to Olympus, θύραζε (for θύρασδε) to the door, Hom.; sometimes repeated with the possess. Pron., ὅνδε δόμονδε; and sometimes even after εἰς, as εἰς ἅλαδε Od.; in Ἀϊδόσδε it follows the gen., = (εἰς ᾍδου (sc. οἶκον). In Attic joined to the names of cities, Ἐλευσῖνάδε, Ἀθήναζε, Θήβαζε (for Ἀθήνασδε, Θήβασδε).
sometimes it denotes purpose only, μή τι φόβονδʼ ἀγόρευε speak not aught tending to fear, Il.
-δε is also used to strengthen certain Pronouns, ὅδε, τοιόσδε, etc.

div1.head: δέ
div1.sense: but: conjunctive Particle, with adversative force: it commonly answers to μέν, and may often be rendered by while, whereas, on the other hand, v. μέν:— but μέν is often omitted, δέ being used merely to pass on from one thing to another; ὣς Ἀχιλεὺς θάμβησεν, θάμβησαν δὲ καὶ ἄλλοι Il.; etc.; κινεῖ κραδίην κινεῖ δὲ χόλον Eur.
δέ is often redundant,

to introduce the apodosis, where it may be rendered by then, yet, εἰ δέ κε μὴ δώωσιν, ἐγὼ δέ κεν αὐτὸς ἕλωμαι if they will not give it, then I will take it, Il.; so at in Lat., si tu oblitus es, at Dii meminerint Catull.
to resume after interruption caused by a parenthesis, where it may be rendered by I say, now, so then, Hdt.
POSITION of δέ: properly second, being often put between the Art. and Subst., the prep. and case.

div1.head: δεράγχη
div1.sense: a collar, Anth.

div1.head: δεραγχής
div1.sense: throttling, Anth.

div1.head: δέραιον
div1.sense: a necklace, Eur.: a collar, Xen.

div1.head: δεραιοπέδη
div1.sense: a collar, Anth.

div1.head: δέργμα
div1.sense: a look, glance, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: δέρκομαι
div1.sense: to see clearly, see, Hom.; δεδορκώς having sight, opp. to τυφλός, Soph.:—hence to be alive, living, Hom., Trag.:—like βλέπω with a neut. adj., δεινόν, σμερδαλέον δ. to look terrible, Hom., etc.; c. acc. cogn., πῦρ δεδορκώς flashing fire from the eyes, Od.; Ἄρη δεδορκότων Aesch.; σκότον δεδ. blind, Eur.
c. acc. to look on or at, Hom., Aesch.:—so, δ. εἴς τινα Eur.; κατά τι Aesch.: generally, to perceive, κτύπον δέδορκα Aesch.

div1.head: δέρμα
div1.sense: the skin, hide, of beasts, Lat. pellis, Hom., etc.; δέρμα κελαινόν, of a shield, Il.:—also of skins prepared for bags or bottles, Od.; of a manʼs skin stript off, Il., Hdt.
later, oneʼs skin, Lat. cutis, περὶ τῶι δέρματι δεδοικέναι Ar.: the shell of a tortoise, Ar.

div1.head: δερμάτινος
div1.sense: of skin, leathern, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: δέρρις
div1.sense: a leathern covering: in pl. screens of hide, Thuc.: cf. διφθέρα.

div1.head: δέρτρον
div1.sense: the membrane which contains the bowels, Lat. omentum, δέρτρον ἔσω δύνοντες even to the bowels, Od.

div1.head: δέρω
div1.sense: to skin, flay, of animals, Hom., etc.:— ἀσκὸν δεδάρθαι to have oneʼs skin flayed off, Solon; so, δερῶ σε θύλακον I will make a purse of your skin, Ar.
also (like the slang words to tan or hide) to cudgel, thrash, Ar.

div1.head: δέσμα
div1.sense: poet. for δεσμός, a bond, fetter, Od.
a head-band, Il.

div1.head: δεσμεύω
div1.sense: to fetter, put in chains, Hhymn., Eur.: to tie together, as corn in the sheaf, Hes.

div1.head: δέσμιος
div1.sense: binding: metaph. binding as with a spell, enchaining, c. gen., ὕμνος δ. φρενῶν Aesch.
pass. bound, in bonds, captive, Soph., Eur., etc.

div1.head: δεσμός
div1.sense: anything for binding, a band, bond, Hom., etc.: a halter, Il.: a mooring-cable, Od.: a door-latch, Od.; a yoke-strap, Xen.
in pl. bonds, fetters, Aesch., Thuc.: in sg., collectively, bonds, imprisonment, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: δεσμοφύλαξ
div1.sense: a gaoler, Luc.

div1.head: δέσμωμα
div1.sense: a bond, fetter, Aesch.

div1.head: δεσμωτήριον
div1.sense: a prison, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: δεσμώτης
div1.sense: a prisoner, captive, Hdt., Attic
as adj. in chains, fettered, Aesch., fem. δεσμῶτις, Soph.

div1.head: δεσπόζω
div1.sense: absol. to be lord or master, gain the mastery, Aesch., Plat.
c. gen. to be lord or master of, Hhymn., Hdt., etc.; δεσπόζειν φόβης to own the lock of hair, Aesch.; metaph. to master, δ. λόγου Aesch.
c. acc. to lord it over, Eur.

div1.head: δέσποινα
div1.sense: the mistress, lady of the house, Lat. hera, of Penelope, Od.
in Attic of goddesses, as Artemis, Soph.; Persephone, Plat.

div1.head: δεσπόσυνος
div1.sense: of or belonging to the master or lord, Hhymn., Aesch.; δ. ἀνάγκαι arbitrary rule, Aesch.
Subst. = δεσπότης, Tyrtae.

div1.head: δεσποτεία
div1.sense: the power of a master over slaves, or the relation of master to slaves, Arist.
absolute sway, despotism, Isocr.

div1.head: δεσποτέω
div1.sense: c. gen., Plat.:—Pass. to be despotically ruled, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: δεσπότης
div1.etym: The latter part -πότης is prob. from same Root as πόσις, and Lat. potis, potior: the syll. δεσ- is uncertain.
div1.sense: a master, lord, the master of the house, Lat. herus, dominus, Aesch., etc.; properly in respect of slaves, so that the address of a slave to his master was ὦ δέσποτʼ ἄναξ or ὦναξ δέσποτα Ar.
of Oriental rulers, a despot, absolute ruler, whose subjects are slaves, Hdt., Thuc.; the pl. is used by Poets of single persons, like τύραννοι, Aesch.
of the gods, Eur., Xen.
generally, an owner, master, lord, κώμου, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: δεσποτικός
div1.sense: of or for a master, δεσποτικαὶ συμφοραί misfortunes that befall oneʼs master, Xen.
of persons, inclined to tyranny, despotic, Plat.

div1.head: δετή
div1.etym: properly fem. of δετός, sub. λαμπάς
div1.sense: sticks bound up, a fagot, torch, Il., Ar.

div1.head: δεῦμα
div1.sense: that which is wet, δεύματα κρεῶν boiled flesh, Pind.

div1.head: δεῦρο
div1.sense: of Place, hither, Lat. huc, with Verbs of motion, Hom., etc.; in a pregn. sense with Verbs of Rest, to (have come hither and) be here, πάρεστι δεῦρο Soph.
used in calling to one, here ! on ! come on ! Lat. adesdum, ἄγε δεῦρο, δεῦρʼ ἄγε, δεῦρʼ ἴθι, δεῦρʼ ἴτω always with a Verb sg. (δεῦτε being used with pl.), Hom.; but with a pl. in Trag.
in arguments, μέχρι δ. τοῦ λόγου up to this point of the argument, Plat.
of Time, until now, up to this time, hitherto, Trag., Plat.: also, δεῦρʼ ἀεί Eur.

div1.head: δευσοποιός
div1.sense: deeply dyed, ingrained, fast, of colours, Plat., Luc.

div1.head: δεύτατος
div1.sense: the last, Il.

div1.head: δεῦτε
div1.sense: as pl. of δεῦρο, hither! come on! come here! just like δεῦρο, with pl. imperat., δεῦτʼ ἄγετʼ Il.; δεῦτε φίλοι Il.; δεῦτʼ ἄγε, Φαιήκων ἡγήτορες Od.

div1.head: δευτεραγωνιστής
div1.sense: the actor who takes second-class parts: metaph. one who seconds a speaker, Dem.

div1.head: δευτεραῖος
div1.sense: on the second day, agreeing with the subject of the Verb, δευτεραῖος ἦν ἐν Σπάρτηι Hdt.; but also, τῆι δευτεραίηι sc. ἡμέραι Hdt.

div1.head: δευτερεῖος
div1.sense: usu. δευτερεῖα sc. ἆθλα, the second prize in a contest; hence the second place or rank, δ. νέμειν τινί Hdt.

div1.head: δευτερεύω
div1.sense: to be second: δευτ. τινί to play second to . . , Plut.

div1.head: δευτερόπρωτον
div1.sense: δευτερόπρωτον, σάββατον the first sabbath after the second day of the feast of unleavened bread, or the first sabbath of the second year (i. e. of the year after the sabbatical year), NTest.

div1.head: δεύτερος
div1.sense: second, being comp. of δύο:

in point of Order, of one who comes in second in a race, Il.: in Attic with Art., ὁ δεύτερος Soph., etc.; αἱ δεύτεραι φροντίδες second thoughts, Eur.; proverb., τὸν δ. πλοῦν to try the next best way, Plat.

of Time, δευτέρηι ἡμέρηι on the next day, Hdt.: c. gen., ἐμεῖο δεύτερος after my time, Il.; δευτέρωι ἔτεϊ τούτων in the year after this, Hdt.: in neut. as adv., δεύτερον αὖ, δεύτερον αὖτις secondly, next, afterwards, a second time, Hom., Attic; in Prose also δεύτερα:— with Art., τὸ δεύτερον Hdt., Aesch., etc.; τὰ δεύτερα Thuc.; ἐκ δευτέρου for the second time, NTest.
in point of Rank, second, δ. μετʼ ἐκεῖνον Hdt.; c. gen., δεύτερος οὐδενός second to none, Hdt.; ἡγεῖσθαι δεύτερον to think quite secondary, Soph.
the second of two, δευτέρη αὐτή herself with another, Hdt.
as Subst., δεύτερα, τά, δευτερεῖα, the second prize or place, Il., Hdt.

div1.head: δεύω
div1.sense: to wet, drench, Il.:—Mid., πτερὰ δεύεται ἅλμηι wets his wings in the brine, Od.
to mix a dry mass with liquid, so as to make it fit to knead, δ. ἄρτον ὕδατι Xen.
Causal, to make to flow, shed, αἷμα Soph.

div1.head: δεύω
div1.sense: to miss, want, ἐδεύησεν ἱκέσθαι he missed, failed in reaching, Od.
as Dep. = Attic δέομαι to feel the want or loss of, be without a thing, c. gen., Il.: to stand in need of, βάκτρου Eur.
to be wanting, deficient in a thing, c. gen., Il.: absol. δευόμενος, in need, Il.
c. gen. pers. to be inferior to, Hom.

div1.head: δέφω
div1.sense: to soften by working with the hand, Ar.

div1.head: δεχήμερος
div1.sense: for ten days, lasting ten days, ἐκεχειρία δεχ. a truce terminable on giving ten daysʼ notice, Thuc.; σπονδαὶ δεχ. Thuc.

div1.head: δέχομαι
div1.sense: of things as the object, to take, accept, receive what is offered, Lat. accipere, Hom., etc.:— δ. τί τινι to receive something at the hand of another, Il.; also τί τινος Il.; τι παρά τινος Hom.; τι ἔκ τινος Soph.:—but also, δ. τί τινος to receive in exchange for . . , χρυσὸν φίλου ἀνδρὸς ἐδέξατο Od.:—also, μᾶλλον δ., c. inf., to take rather, to choose to do or be, Xen.; and without μᾶλλον, οὐδεὶς ἂν δέξαιτο φεύγειν Thuc.
to accept graciously, Il.; δ. τὸν οἰωνόν to accept, hail the omen, Hdt., etc.:— to accept or approve, τοὺς λόγους, τὴν ξυμμαχίην Hdt., Thuc.
simply to give ear to, hear, Lat. accipere, Eur., Thuc.
to take or regard as so and so, μηδὲ συμφορὰν δέχου τὸν ἄνδρα Soph.
of persons, to receive hospitably, entertain, Hom., Attic
to greet, worship, Il.; δ. τινα ξύμμαχον to accept as an ally, Thuc.
to receive as an enemy, to await the attack of, Lat. excipere, Il.; of a hunter waiting for game or a wild boar waiting for the hunters, Il.; τοὺς πολεμίους δ. Hdt., etc.
to expect, c. acc. et inf. fut., Od.: or c. acc. to wait for, Od.; μηδὲ συμφορὰν δέχου τὸν ἄνδρα do not expect him to be . . , Soph.
absol. to succeed, come next, δέχεται κακὸν ἐκ κακοῦ Il.; ἄλλος δʼ ἐξ ἄλλου δέχεται ἆθλος Hes.; of places, Ἀρτεμίσιον δέκεται Hdt.

div1.head: δέψω
div1.sense: to work or knead a thing till it is soft, κηρὸν δεψήσας Od.; δέψει τὸ δέρμα Hdt.

div1.head: δέω
div1.sense: to bind, tie, fetter, δεσμῶι τινα δῆσαι Il., etc.:—c. acc. only, to bind, put in bonds, Od., Attic
metaph. to bind, enchain, γλῶσσα δέ οἱ δέδεται Theogn.; ψυχὰ δέδεται λύπηι Eur.
c. gen. to let or stop one from a thing, ἔδησε κελεύθου Od.
Mid. to bind, tie, put on oneself (cf. ὑποδέω) , ποσσὶ δʼ ὑπαὶ ἐδήσατο πέδιλα tied them on his feet, Il.; and in Pass., περὶ κνήμηισι κνημῖδας δέδετο he had greaves bound round his legs, Od.

div1.head: δέω
div1.sense: to lack, miss, stand in need of a person or thing, c. gen., Il., Xen.:— πολλοῦ δέω I want much, i. e. am far from, c. inf., πολλοῦ δέω ἀπολογεῖσθαι I am far from defending myself, Plat.; μικροῦ ἔδεον εἶναι Xen.; and absol., πολλοῦ γε δέω far from it, Plat.; τοῦ παντὸς δέω Aesch.; v. δεῖ II:—so in partic., δυοῖν δέοντα τεσσεράκοντα forty lacking two, thirty-eight, Hdt.; ἑνὸς δέον εἰκοστὸν ἔτος the 20th year save one, the 19th, Thuc.
as Dep. δέομαι: fut. δεήσομαι: aor1 ἐδεήθην:
to be in want or need, κάρτα δεόμενος Hdt.:— to stand in need of a person or thing, c. gen., Hdt., Soph.; οὐδὲν δέομαί τινος I have no need of him, Thuc.: c. inf., τοῦτο ἔτι δέομαι μαθεῖν Plat.

to ask for a thing from a person, c. dupl. gen. rei et pers., Hdt., Thuc.; also, τοῦτο δέομαι ὑμῶν Plat.; and c. acc. cogn., δέημα or δέησιν δεῖσθαί τινος Ar., etc., rarely with gen. pers. only, δεηθεὶς ὑμῶν having begged a favour of you, Dem.:—c. gen. pers. et inf. to beg a person to do, Hdt., Plat.
div1.etym: The Aeolic form δεύω (v. δεύω 2) shows that the *root of this word was δεϝ.

div1.head: δῆγμα
div1.sense: a bite, sting, Xen.: metaph., δ. λύπης Aesch.

div1.head: δηγμός
div1.sense: the act of biting: in pl. caustics, Plut.

div1.head: δηθά
div1.sense: for a long time, Lat. diu, Hom.

div1.head: δῆθεν
div1.sense: a strengthd. form of δή, really, in very truth, τί δὴ ἀνδρωθέντες δῆθεν ποιήσουσι; what then will they do when they are really grown up? Hdt.:— also epexegetic, Lat. videlicet, that is to say, Aesch., Eur.:—ironically, Lat. scilicet, to imply that a statement is not true, οἵ μιν ἠθέλησαν ἀπολέσαι δῆθεν as he pretended, Hdt.; φέροντες ὡς ἄγρην δῆθεν Hdt.

div1.head: δηθύνω
div1.sense: to tarry, be long, delay, Il.

div1.head: δηϊάλωτος
div1.sense: taken by the enemy, captive, Eur.; contr. δηιάλωτος Aesch.

div1.head: Δηιάνειρα
div1.sense: destroying her spouse, the wife of Hercules, —her name expressing the legend of his death, Soph.

div1.head: δηϊοτής
div1.sense: battle-strife, battle, death, Hom.

div1.head: δηϊόω
div1.sense: to cut down, slay, Il.: to cleave asunder, Il.; savage beast, to rend, tear, Il.; τὸν πώγωνα δεδηιωμένος having had his beard cut off, Luc.
to waste or ravage a country, Hdt., Thuc.; ἄστυ δηιώσειν πυρί Soph.

div1.head: δηκτήριος
div1.sense: biting, torturing, c. gen., Eur.

div1.head: δήκτης
div1.sense: a biter, Anth.

div1.head: δηκτικός
div1.sense: able to bite, biting, stinging, Luc.

div1.head: δηλαδή
div1.sense: quite clearly, manifestly, Soph., Eur., etc.:—also iron., προφάσιος τῆσδε δηλαδή on this pretext forsooth, Hdt.:—in answers, yes of course, Ar.

div1.head: δηλέομαι
div1.etym: perf. δεδήλημαι both in act. and pass. sense
div1.sense: Dep.: of persons, to hurt, do a mischief to, Hom.; μή με δηλήσεται (Epic for -ηται) Od.; so in Hdt.; to hurt by magic potions, Theocr.
of things, to damage, spoil, waste, καρπὸν ἐδηλήσαντʼ Il.; γῆν δηλησάμενος Hdt.:—esp. in phrase, ὅρκια δηλήσασθαι to violate a truce, Il.
absol. to do mischief, be hurtful, Hom.

div1.head: δήλημα
div1.sense: a mischief, bane, Od., Soph.

div1.head: δηλήμων
div1.sense: baneful, noxious, βροτῶν δηλήμονα baneful to them, Od.; ἀνθρώπων οὐ δηλήμονες doing men no hurt, Hdt.

div1.head: δήλησις
div1.sense: mischief, ruin, bane, Hdt.

div1.head: δηλητήρ
div1.sense: a destroyer, Epic Hom.

div1.head: Δηλιάς
div1.sense: a Delian woman, Hhymn., Eur.
Δηλιάς, sc. ναῦς the Delian ship, sent from Athens every fourth year in memory of Theseus, Plat.

div1.head: Δήλιος
div1.sense: Delian, Trag., etc.:—ὁ Δ., name of Apollo, Soph., etc.
a Delian, Hdt., etc.
τὰ Δήλια (sc. ἱερά) the quinquennial festival of Apollo at Delos, Thuc.

div1.head: Δηλογενής
div1.sense: Delos-born, Simon.

div1.head: δηλονότι
div1.sense: i. e. δῆλόν ἐστιν ὅτι, used parenthetically, quite clearly, manifestly, plainly, Plat., etc.
epexegetically, that is to say, namely, Lat. scilicet, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: δηλοποιέω
div1.sense: to make clear, Plut.

div1.head: δῆλος
div1.sense: properly, visible, conspicuous, Il.

clear to the mind, manifest, evident, Od.: —δῆλός εἰμι with partic., δῆλός ἐστιν ἀλγεινῶς φέρων i. e. it is clear that he takes it ill, Soph.; δῆλοί εἰσι μὴ ἐπιτρέψοντες it is clear that they will not permit, Thuc.; also, acc. to our idiom, δῆλόν ἐστιν ὅτι . . , v. δηλονότι.
δῆλον itself is used like δηλαδή, as αὐτὸς πρὸς αὑτοῦ· δῆλον, all by himself, ʼtis manifest, Soph.:—also, δῆλον δέ to introduce a proof, Thuc.

div1.head: Δῆλος
div1.etym: Prob. from δῆλος, because of the legend that it became visible by rising from the sea.
div1.sense: Delos, one of the Cyclades, birthplace of Apollo and Artemis, Od.; called also Ὀρτυγία.

div1.head: δηλόω
div1.etym: Pass., fut. δηλωθήσομαι and in mid. form δηλώσομαι
div1.sense: to make visible or manifest, to show, exhibit, Soph.:—Pass. to be or become manifest, Soph.
to make known, disclose, reveal, Aesch., Soph.
to prove, Soph., Thuc.
to declare, explain, set forth, indicate, signify, Thuc.; c. part., δηλώσω σε κακόν ὄντα Soph.; the partic., if it refers to the nom. of the Verb, is itself in nom., δηλώσει γεγενημένος Thuc.
intr. to be clear or plain, Hdt., Plat.
impers., δηλοῖ δῆλόν ἐστι, Hdt.; fut. δηλώσει Plat.; aor1 ἐδήλωσε Xen.

div1.head: δήλωσις
div1.sense: a pointing out, manifestation, explaining, shewing, Thuc.; δ. ποιεῖσθαι δηλοῦν, Thuc.

div1.head: δημαγωγέω
div1.sense: to lead the people, in bad sense, Ar.
c. acc. pers. to win by popular arts, Xen.

div1.head: δημαγωγία
div1.sense: leadership of the people, Ar.

div1.head: δημαγωγικός
div1.sense: fit for or like a demagogue, Ar.

div1.head: δημαγωγός
div1.sense: a popular leader, of Pericles, Isocr.: commonly in bad sense, a leader of the mob, a demagogue, such as Cleon, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: δημάρατος
div1.sense: pryaed for by the people: as prop. n. of a king of Sparta, Hdt.

div1.head: δημαρχέω
div1.sense: to be demarch, Dem.

div1.head: δημαρχία
div1.sense: the office or rank of δήμαρχος, Dem.: the tribunate, Plut.

div1.head: δημαρχικός
div1.sense: tribunician, Plut.

div1.head: δήμαρχος
div1.sense: a governor of the people:
at Athens, a demarch, the president of a δῆμος, who managed its affairs, Ar., Dem.
at Rome, a tribune of the plebs, Plut.

div1.head: δημεραστής
div1.sense: a friend of the people, Plat.

div1.head: δήμευσις
div1.sense: confiscation of oneʼs property, Plat.

div1.head: δημεύω
div1.sense: to declare public property, to confiscate, Lat. publicare, Thuc., etc.
generally, to make public, δεδήμευται κράτος the power is in the hands of the people, Eur.

div1.head: δημηγορέω
div1.sense: to speak in the assembly, Lat. concionari, Ar., etc.: Pass., τὰ δεδημηγορημένα public speeches, Dem.
to make popular speeches, to speak rhetorically, use clap-trap, Plat., etc.

div1.head: δημηγορία
div1.sense: a speech in the public assembly, Aeschin.
popular oratory, clap-trap, Plat.

div1.head: δημηγορικός
div1.sense: of or for public speaking, qualified for it, Xen.: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , δημηγορία, Plat.

div1.head: δημηγόρος
div1.sense: a popular orator, mostly in a bad sense, Plat.:— τιμαὶ δ. a speakerʼs honours, Eur.

div1.head: Δημήτηρ
div1.etym: The Deriv. from δῆ γῆ, quasi Γημήτηρ is improbable, v. δᾶ.
div1.sense: Demeter, Lat. Ceres, goddess of agriculture, mother of Persephone, Hom.

div1.head: δημίζω
div1.sense: to affect popularity, cheat the people, Ar.

div1.head: δημιοπληθής
div1.sense: abounding in public, κτήνη δ. cattle of which the people have large store, Aesch.

div1.head: δημιόπρατα
div1.sense: goods sold by public authority: confiscated goods, Ar.

div1.head: δήμιος
div1.sense: belonging to the people, public, Od.; αἰσυμνῆται δ. judges elected by the people, Od.; neut. pl. as adv., δήμια πίνειν at the public cost, Il.
ὁ δήμιος (sc. δοῦλος), the public executioner, Plat., etc.

div1.head: δημιουργέω
div1.sense: to practise a trade, do work, Plat.
c. acc. rei, to work at, fabricate, Plat.
to be one of the δημιουργοί (II), Plat.

div1.head: δημιουργία
div1.sense: a making, creating, Plat.
workmanship, handicraft, Plat.; δ. τῶν τεχνῶν practising them, Plat..

div1.head: δημιουργικός
div1.sense: of or for a δημιουργός or handicraftsman, Plat.

div1.head: δημιουργός
div1.sense: one who works for the people, a skilled workman, handicraftsman, Od., etc.; of medical practitioners, Plat.; of sculptors, Plat.:—generally, a framer, maker; λόγων Aeschin.; πειθοῦς δημιουργὸς ἡ ῥητορική Plat.: metaph., ὄρθρος δημιοεργός morn that calls man to work, Hhymn.
the Maker of the world, Xen., Plat.
in some Peloponnesian states, the name of a magistrate, Thuc., Dem.

div1.head: δημοβόρος
div1.sense: devourer of the people, Il.

div1.head: δημογέρων
div1.sense: an elder of the people, chief, Il.: δημογ. θεός, Lat. deus minorum gentium, Anth.

div1.head: δημόθεν
div1.sense: at the public cost, Od.
δημόθεν Εὐπυρίδης an Eupyrian by deme, i. e. by birth, place, Anth.

div1.head: δημοθοινία
div1.sense: a public feast, Luc.

div1.head: δημόθροος
div1.sense: uttered by the people, Aesch.; δ. ἀναρχία lawlessness of popular clamour, Aesch.

div1.head: δημοκηδής
div1.sense: friend of the people, Lat. poplicola, Plut.

div1.head: δημοκόλαξ
div1.sense: a mob-flatterer, Luc.

div1.head: δημοκοπέω
div1.sense: to curry mob-favour, Plut.

div1.head: δημοκοπικός
div1.sense: of or for a demagogue, Plat.

div1.head: δημοκόπος
div1.sense: a demagogue.

div1.head: δημόκραντος
div1.sense: ratified by the people, Aesch.

div1.head: δημοκρατέομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to have a democratical constitution, live in a democracy, Hdt., Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: δημοκρατία
div1.sense: democracy, popular government, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: δημοκρατικός
div1.sense: of or for a democracy, Ar., Plat.
of persons, favouring democracy, Plat.

div1.head: δημόλευστος
div1.sense: publicly stoned, δ. φόνος death by public stoning, Soph.

div1.head: δημόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to talk popularly, Pind., Plat.

div1.head: δημοπίθηκος
div1.sense: a mob-monkey, charlatan, Ar.

div1.head: δημοποίητος
div1.sense: made a citizen, not one by birth, Plut.

div1.head: δημορριφής
div1.sense: hurled by the people, Aesch.

div1.head: Δημοσθενίζω
div1.sense: to imitate Demosthenes, Plut.

div1.head: δημοσιεύω
div1.sense: to confiscate, like δημεύω, Xen.: Pass., τὰ δεδημοσιευμένα popular sayings, Arist.
intr. to be in the public service, of physicians, Ar., Plat.: generally, to be a public man, opp. to ἰδιωτεύω, Plat.

div1.head: δημόσιος
div1.sense: belonging to the people or state, Lat. publicus, opp. to ἴδιος, Hdt., Attic:— δημόσιον εἶναι, γίγνεσθαι to be confiscated, Thuc., Plat.
as Subst., ὁ δημόσιος (sc. δοῦλος), a public servant, as the public crier, Hdt.; a public notary, Dem.
as neut., δημόσιον, ου, τό, the state, Lat. respublica, Hdt., Attic
any public building, a public hall, Hdt.
the treasury, elsewhere τὸ κοινόν, Dem.
the public prison, Thuc.
τὰ δημόσια (sc. χρήματα) state-property, Ar.
as fem., ἡ δαμοσία (sc. σκηνή) the tent of the Spartan kings, Xen.
as adv.:
dat. δημοσίαι, Ionic -ίηι, at the public expense, Hdt.; by public consent, Dem.; δ. τεθνάναι to die by the executioner, Dem.
neut. pl. δημόσια, at the public cost, Ar.

div1.head: δημοσιόω
div1.sense: to confiscate, like δημοσιεύω, Thuc.
Pass. to be published, Plat.

div1.head: δημοσιώνης
div1.sense: a farmer of the revenue, Lat. publicanus, Strab.

div1.head: δημός
div1.sense: fat, Il., Ar., etc.; δίπλακι δημῶι (of sacrificial meat) with fat above and fat below, Il.

div1.head: δῆμος
div1.sense: a country-district, country, land, Hom.

the people of a country, the commons, Lat. plebs, δήμου ἀνήρ, opp. to βασιλεύς, Il., etc.; of a single person, δῆμος ἐών being a commoner, Il.:—in historians, the commons, commonalty, opp. to οἱ εὐδαίμονες, οἱ παχέες, οἱ δυνατοί, Hdt., Thuc.; of soldiers, opp. to officers, Xen.
like πλῆθος, the commons, the democracy, opp. to οἱ ὀλίγοι, Hdt., Ar., etc.
in Attica, δῆμοι, οἱ, townships or hundreds, = Doric κῶμαι, Lat. pagi, ancient divisions of the county, being (in the time of Hdt.) 100 in number, 10 in each φυλή.

div1.head: δημοτελής
div1.sense: at the public cost, public, national, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: δημότερος
div1.sense: common, vulgar, Anth.

div1.head: δημότης
div1.sense: one of the people, a commoner, plebeian, Hdt., Attic
one of the same people, a fellow-citizen, Eur.
at Athens, one of the same deme, Soph.

div1.head: δημοτικός
div1.sense: of or for the people, in common use, common, δ. γράμματα in Egypt, opp. to the hieroglyphics, Hdt.
of the populace, one of them, Lat. plebeius, Xen., Dem.
on the popular or democratic side, Lat. popularis, Ar., Thuc., etc.: adv. -κῶς, affably, kindly, Dem.

div1.head: δημοῦχος
div1.sense: protecting the people, of guardian deities, Soph.; δημοῦχοι γᾶς ruling the people of the land, Soph.

div1.head: δημοχαριστής
div1.sense: a mob-courtier, Eur.

div1.head: δημώδης
div1.sense: of the people, popular, Plat.

div1.head: δήμωμα
div1.sense: a popular pastime, χαρίτων δαμώματα odes for public performance, Stesich, ap. Ar.

div1.head: δημωφελής
div1.sense: of public use, Plat.

div1.head: δηναιός
div1.sense: long-lived, Il., Theocr.
old, aged, ancient, Aesch.

div1.head: δηνάριον
div1.sense: a Roman coin, a denary, nearly = Gr. δραχμή, NTest.

div1.head: δήνεα
div1.sense: counsels, plans, arts, whether good or bad, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: δήν
div1.sense: long, for a long while, Lat. diu, Il.; οὐ δὴν ἦν he was not long-lived, Il.
long ago, Od.
of Place, far, much, δὴν χάζετο Il.

div1.head: δῆξις
div1.sense: a bite, biting: metaph. of biting jokes, Plut.

div1.head: δή
div1.sense: Particle used to give greater exactness, to the word or words which it influences (prob. a shortened form of ἤδη, Lat. iam) now, in truth, indeed, surely, really.
Usage of δή with single words:

after Adjectives, οἶος δή, μόνος δή, all alone, Od., etc.; esp. such as imply magnitude, μέγας δή, μικρὸς δή, etc.; often with Superlatives, μέγιστος δή, κράτιστος δή quite the greatest, confessedly the best, Thuc.; so with Numerals, ὀκτώ δὴ προέηκα ὀϊστούς I have shot full eight arrows, Il.; εἷς δή one only, Eur., etc.

after Adverbs, πολλάκις δή many times and oft, often ere now, Lat. jam saepe, Il.; ὀψὲ δὲ δή quite late, Il.; νῦν δή even now, now first, now at length, Xen., etc.:— τότε δή at that very time, Thuc.; αὐτίκα δὴ μάλα on the very spot, Plat.; also, ναὶ δή yea verily, Il.; οὐ δή surely not, Soph.
with Verbs, δὴ γὰρ ἴδον ὀφθαλμοῖσι for verily I saw him, Il.
with Substantives, ἐς δὴ τὸ Ἄργος τοῦτο . . well to this A. they came, Hdt.; τέλος δή its complete end, Aesch.; ironically, Lat. scilicet, εἰσήγαγε τὰς ἑταιρίδας δή the pretended courtesans, Xen.

with Pronouns, to mark strongly, ἐμὲ δή a man like me, Hdt.; σὺ δή you of all persons, Hdt.; οὗτος δή this and no other, Hdt.; ὅς δή who plainly, Il.:—with indef. Pronouns, ἄλλοι δή others be they who they may, Il.; δή τις some one or other, Lat. nescio quis, Plat.; δή τι in any way, whatever it be, Il., Hdt.
in reference to whole clauses:
to continue a narrative, so then, so, τότε μὲν δὴ ἡσυχίην εἶχε Hdt.; in summing up, τοιαῦτα μὲν δὴ ταῦτα, Lat. haec hactenus, Aesch.
in inferences, Hdt., etc.; esp. to express what is unexpected, καὶ σὺ δή so then you too! Aesch.
with Imperat. and Subj., ἐννοεῖτε γὰρ δή for do but consider, Xen.; so, ἄγε δή, φέρε δή, ἴθι δή, σκόπει δή, etc.
γε δή to express what follows a fortiori, μετὰ ὅπλων γε δή above all with arms, Thuc.; μή τί γε δή not to mention that, Dem.
καὶ δή and what is more, Il.: so, ἐς Αἴγυπτον ἀπίκετο, καὶ δὴ καὶ ἐς Σάρδις he came to Egypt, and what is more to Sardis also, Hdt.; ἰσχὺς καὶ κάλλος καὶ πλοῦτος δή and above all riches, Plat.
καὶ δή is also in answers, βλέψον κάτω. Answ. καὶ δὴ βλέπω, well, I am looking, Ar.
in assumptions, καὶ δὴ δέδεγμαι and now suppose I have accepted, Aesch.

div1.head: δήποθεν
div1.sense: from any quarter, Lat. undecunque, Aesch.

div1.head: δήποτε
div1.sense: at some time, once upon a time, Od., Aesch., etc.
εἰ δή ποτε, Lat. si quando, Il.; ὁπόθεν δή ποτε from some quarter or other, Dem.
as interrog., τί δή ποτε; what in the world? quid tandem? Dem.; πόσοι δή ποτε; how many do you suppose? Dem.

div1.head: δήπουθεν
div1.sense: indef. adv., much like δήπου, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: δήπου
div1.sense: perhaps, it may be, Il.; in Attic doubtless, I suppose, I presume, of course, Lat. scilicet, οὐ δήπου τλητόν Aesch., etc.: often in phrases, ἴστε γὰρ δή που, μέμνησθε γὰρ δή που Dem.; so, as interrog. implying an affirm. answer, τὴν αἰχμάλωτον κάτοισθα δή που; I presume you know, Soph.

div1.head: δηριάομαι
div1.sense: to contend, wrangle, Hom.

div1.head: δῆρις
div1.sense: a fight, battle, contest, Il., Aesch.

div1.head: δηρόβιος
div1.sense: long-lived, Aesch.

div1.head: δηρός
div1.sense: long, too long, δηρὸν χρόνον Il.; so, δηρὸν (sub. χρόνον) as adv. all too long, Il.; ἐπὶ δηρόν Il.; δαρὸν χρόνον Soph.

div1.head: δῆτα
div1.sense: certainly, to be sure, of course:
in answers, added to a word which echoes the question, ἴσασιν; do they know? Answ. ἴσασι δῆτα aye they know, Eur.; often with a negat., οὐ δῆτʼ ἔγωγε faith not I, Ar.

in questions, mostly to mark an inference or consequence, τί δῆτα; what then? πῶς δῆτα; ἆρα δῆτα, etc. Trag.:— sometimes it expresses indignation, καὶ δῆτʼ ἐτόλμας; and so thou hast dared? Soph.; ταῦτα δῆτʼ ἀνασχετά; Soph.; ironical, τῶι σῶι δικαίωι δῆτʼ; your principle of justice forsooth, Soph.
in prayers or wishes, ἀπόλοιο δῆτα now a murrain take thee! Ar.; σκόπει δῆτα only look, Plat., etc.

div1.head: Δηῷος
div1.sense: sacred to Demeter, Anth.

div1.head: Δηώ
div1.sense: Demeter, Hhymn., Soph., etc.

div1.head: δήω
div1.sense: to find, meet with, Hom.

div1.head: διαβάθρα
div1.sense: a shipʼs ladder, Luc.

div1.head: διαβαίνω
div1.sense: to make a stride, walk or stand with the legs apart, εὖ διαβάς of a man planting himself firmly for fighting, Il.
c. acc. to step across, pass over a ditch or river, Il.
absol. (θάλασσαν or ποταμόν being omitted), to cross over, Lat. trajicere, ἐς Ἤλιδα Od.; πλοίῳ διαβῆναι Hdt., etc.

div1.head: διαβάλλω
div1.sense: to throw over or across, to carry over or across, νέας Hdt.: hence,
seemingly intr., like Lat. trajicere, to pass over, cross, pass, Hdt.: also c. acc., δ. γεφύρας Eur.; πέλαγος Thuc.
to set at variance, make a quarrel between, ἐμὲ καὶ Ἀγάθωνα Plat.:—Pass. to be at variance with, τινί Plat.

to traduce, slander, calumniate, Hdt., etc.; διέβαλον τοὺς Ἴωνας ὡς . . traduced them saying that . . , Hdt.:—Pass., διαβάλλεσθαί τινι to be filled with suspicion against another, Hdt.; πρός τινα Hdt.; ἔς τινα Thuc.
c. acc. rei, to misrepresent a thing, to state slanderously, Hdt., Dem.: to give hostile information, without insinuation of falsehood, Thuc.
to deceive by false accounts, impose upon, τινά Hdt.:—so in Mid., Hdt.:—Pass., διαβεβλῆσθαι ὡς . . to be slanderously told that . . , Plat.

div1.head: διαβαπτίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to dive for a match: metaph. to contend in foul language with, τινι Dem.

div1.head: διάβασις
div1.sense: a crossing over, passage, δ. ποιεῖσθαι Hdt.
a means or place of crossing, Hdt.: δ. ποταμοῦ a ford, Thuc.: a bridge, Xen.

div1.head: διαβάσκω
div1.sense: to strut about, Ar.

div1.head: διαβαστάζω
div1.sense: to weigh in the hand, estimate, Plut.

div1.head: διαβατέος
div1.sense: that can be crossed or passed through, Xen.

div1.head: διαβατήρια
div1.sense: sc. ἱερά, τά offerings before crossing the border, τὰ δ. προὐχώρει, τὰ δ. ἐγένετο they were favourable, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: διαβατός
div1.sense: to be crossed or passed, fordable, Hdt., etc.; νῆσον δ. ἐξ ἠπείρου easily got at from the main land, Hdt.

div1.head: διαβεβαιόω
div1.sense: Usu. mid. διαβεβαιόομαι, to maintain strongly, Dem.

div1.head: διαβήτης
div1.sense: the compass, so called from its outstretched legs, Lat. circinus, Ar.

div1.head: διαβιβάζω
div1.sense: to carry over or across, to transport, δ. τὸν στρατὸν κατὰ γεφύρας Hdt.; ἐς τὴν νῆσον τοὺς ὁπλίτας Thuc.

div1.head: διαβιβρώσκω
div1.sense: to eat up, Plat.:—Pass., perf. inf. διαβεβρῶσθαι Luc.

div1.head: διαβιόω
div1.sense: to live through, pass, χρόνον, βίον Plat., etc.:—absol. to spend oneʼs whole life, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: διαβλέπω
div1.sense: to look straight before one, Plat.

div1.head: διαβοάω
div1.sense: to shout out, proclaim, publish, Aesch.:—Pass. to be the common talk, Luc.
to cry out, Thuc.
Mid. to contend in shouting, Dem.

div1.head: διαβόητος
div1.sense: noised abroad, famous, Plut.

div1.head: διαβολή
div1.sense: false accusation, slander, calumny, ἐπὶ διαβολῇ εἰπεῖν Hdt.; διαβολὰς ἐνδέχεσθαι to give ear to false accusations, Hdt.; ἐμὴ δ. the slanders against me, Plat.
a quarrel, enmity, Thuc.

div1.head: διάβολος
div1.sense: slanderous, backbiting, Sup.; διαβολώτατος Ar.
as Subst. a slanderer, Arist.: the slanderer, the Devil, NTest.
adv. -λως, injuriously, invidiously, Thuc.

div1.head: διαβόρος
div1.sense: eating through, devouring, Soph.
proparox. διάβορος, ον, pass. eaten through, consumed, Soph.

div1.head: διαβουκολέω
div1.sense: to cheat with false hopes, Luc.

div1.head: διαβουλεύω
div1.sense: Mostly mid., to discuss pro and con, discuss thoroughly, Thuc.

div1.head: διαβούλιον
div1.sense: counsel, deliberation, Polyb.

div1.head: διαβρέχω
div1.sense: to wet through, soak, Aesch.

div1.head: διάβροχος
div1.sense: very wet, moist, Eur.: ναῦς δ. ships with their timbers soaked and rotten, Thuc.:—metaph., ἔρωτι, μέθῃ δ. Luc.

div1.head: διαβυνέω
div1.sense: to thrust through so as to stop up:— Mid., διαβυνέονται ὀϊστοὺς διὰ τῆς ἀριστερῆς they pass arrows through their left hand, Hdt.:—Pass., πηδάλιον διὰ τῆς τρόπιος διαβύνεται is passed through the keel, Hdt.

div1.head: διαγαληνίζω
div1.sense: to make quite calm, Ar.

div1.head: διαγανακτέω
div1.sense: to be full of indignation, Dem.

div1.head: διαγανάκτησις
div1.sense: great indignation, Plut.

div1.head: διαγγέλλω
div1.sense: to give notice by a messenger, to send as a message, Xen.:—generally, to noise abroad, proclaim, Eur., Plat.; c. inf. to order to do, Eur.:—Mid. to pass the word of command from man to man, inform one another, Xen.

div1.head: διάγγελος
div1.sense: a messenger, Lat. internuncius, esp. a secret informant, go-between, spy, Thuc.

div1.head: διαγελάω
div1.sense: to laugh at, τινα Eur., Xen.

div1.head: διαγίγνομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:— to go through, pass, τόσαδε ἔτη Plat.; τὴν νύκτα Xen.: absol. to go through life, survive, live, Ar., etc.; c. part., διαγίγνεσθαι ἄρχων to continue in the government, Xen.; οὐδὲν ἄλλο ποιῶν διαγεγένηται he never did anything else, Xen.
to be between, intervene, ap. Dem.

div1.head: διαγιγνώσκω
div1.sense: to distinguish, discern, Lat. dignoscere, διαγνῶναι ἄνδρα ἕκαστον Il.; δ. εἰ ὁμοῖοί εἰσι whether they are equals or no, Hdt.; δ. τὸ ὀρθὸν καὶ μή Aeschin.:— δ. τινὰς ὄντας, i. e. δ. οἵτινές εἰσιν, Ar.
to discern exactly, τι Soph.
to resolve, vote to do so and so, c. inf., Hdt.:—Pass., impers. διέγνωστο it had been resolved, Thuc.
as Athen. law-term, to decide a suit, Lat. dijudicare, δίκην Aesch.:— to give judgment, περί τινος Thuc.

div1.head: διαγκυλίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to hold a javelin by the thongPass., perf. part. pass. διηγκυλισμένος, of a man, ready to shoot, Xen.:—so (from δι-αγκυλόομαι) , διηγκυλωμένος Xen.

div1.head: διαγλάφω
div1.sense: to scoop out, Od.

div1.head: διάγλυπτος
div1.sense: carved in intaglio, engraved, Anth.

div1.head: διαγλύφω
div1.sense: to carve in intaglio, Diod.

div1.head: διαγνώμη
div1.sense: a decree, resolution, Thuc.

div1.head: διαγνωρίζω
div1.sense: to make known, NTest.

div1.head: διάγνωσις
div1.sense: a distinguishing, discernment, Eur., Dem.
power of discernment, Eur.
a resolving, deciding, δ. ποιεῖσθαι to decide a matter, Thuc.; δ. περί τινος Dem.

div1.head: διαγνωστέος
div1.sense: one must distinguish, Luc.

div1.head: διαγνωστικός
div1.sense: able to distinguish, Luc.

div1.head: διαγογγύζω
div1.sense: to murmur among themselves, NTest.

div1.head: διαγορεύω
div1.sense: to speak plainly, declare, Hdt.
to speak of, κακῶς δ. τινά Luc.

div1.head: διάγραμμα
div1.sense: that which is marked out by lines, a figure, plan, Plat.
a geometrical figure, diagram, Xen., Plat.
a written list, register, Dem.
a decree, edict, Plut.

div1.head: διαγραφή
div1.sense: a marking off by lines, Plat.: a geometrical figure, diagram, outline, Plut.

div1.head: διαγράφω
div1.sense: to mark out by lines, delineate, Plat.
to draw a line through, cross out, strike off the list, Plat.; δ. δίκην to strike a cause out of the list, cancel, quash it, Ar.

div1.head: διαγρυπνέω
div1.sense: to lie awake, Ar.

div1.head: διάγω
div1.sense: to carry over or across, Od., Thuc., etc.
of Time, to go through, pass, spend, βίοτον, βίον Aesch., etc.

intr. (without βίον) to pass life, live, like Lat. degere, Hdt., etc.:— to delay, put off time, Thuc.:— to continue, Xen.: c. part. to continue doing so and so, δ. μανθάνων Xen.; also with adv., ἄριστα Xen.
to make to continue or keep in a certain state, πόλιν ὀρθοδίκαιον δ. Aesch.; διῆγεν ὑμᾶς Dem.
to entertain a person, Xen.

div1.head: διαγωγή
div1.sense: a passing of life, a way or course of life, Lat. ratio vitae, Plat., etc.; διαγωγαὶ τοῦ συζῆν public pastimes, Arist.

div1.head: διαγωγικός
div1.sense: of or for a passage: τέλος δ. a transit duty, Strab.

div1.head: διαγωνίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to contend, struggle or fight against, τινι and πρός τινα Xen.
to fight desperately, contend earnestly, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: διαδάπτω
div1.sense: to tear asunder, rend, Il.

div1.head: διαδατέομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:
in reciprocal sense, to divide among themselves, διὰ κτῆσιν δατέοντο Il., Hes.
